story:
Short Summary

WHO AND WHAT
My name is Darla, and I'm an artist.  I work in ink and colored pencil, my subjects are fantasy and erotica.  My work falls between the niches of Fine Art, Illustration, and Design.  In 40 years of selling my work, I have encountered many other artists in the same position.  Interstitial art* can be sold online, but, as any artist will tell you, at some point, you have to get your work on a wall.
*examples of interstitial art: Gritty spiritual art, fully dressed erotica, non-sequential graphic art, cremation sarcophagi, un-recognized "fine art" mediums, such as taxidermy.
I am also a social activist in a small way.  I work with support groups for people who are kinky, fetishists, trans gendered, or otherwise part of interstitial culture.  To others, we may be freaks and geeks, but to me, it's Family.

I want Unseen Gallery to become:
  • A place for artists whose work falls between the niches to show their work.
  • A place collectors can see what's not shown anywhere else.
  • A place for meetings, classes, and small gatherings on interstitial topics.
  • A place where people with unusual tastes can socialise without worrying about being judged.
I don't expect to change the world, I just want to improve this little corner of it.  The result should be more confident people moving out into the world at large.  Once the space has become known as a friendly and comfortable meeting place, it should be able to support itself.  The demographics of Albuquerque show a need for this size of meeting space.  

What We Need & What You Get

We already have a space.  We had financial backing from an individual, but that has failed. (for his family's privacy, I will not go into details)  There are plenty of talented volunteers who share my vision, to help run the place.  We have good legal advice to help us know when there is a conflict between the First Amendment, and city zoning.  We even have a webmonkey who will be able to keep our websites up to date.  

What we need is operating capital to cover expenses until the business end of things has stabilized.  This will be used for rent, utilities and advertizing.  

The reward will be a thriving community for creative thought and expression.  Also comfy chairs.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Send good interstitial artists our way.
  • Come check out the gallery in person.

story:
La Calavera Catrina ('Dapper Skeleton', 'Elegant Skull') is a 1910–1913 zinc etching by famous Mexican printmaker, cartoon illustrator and lithographer Jose Guadalupe Posada

The completed installation "La Novia del Teatro" inspired by Posada's illustration of "La Pata de Cabra". (Total Height: 7 feet)

The Mulvane Museum of Art, Washburn University, Topeka, KS.

For information on sponsorship opportunities, please contact project representative Eva Nightingale at 972-835-5524 or enightingale@outlook.com

story:
Play with me – be part of my first solo show

Who doesn’t love to be taken care of? Who doesn’t dream to play all day long, to concentrate on achieving immediate pleasures without suffering the consequences of her irresponsibility? As we grow up, we exchange our playfulness for role play, acting and gender play, tasks that require a persistent oppression of our inner child. Whether boys or girls, children love to swim naked, can be satisfied with simple things and sometimes are afraid of the dark. Children are selfish without being apologetic about it. This changes as we become adults. Especially, in the case of females, since women are measured in society by their abilities to care for others, for their self-sacrifice, for their capabilities as mothers. Even in modern society, women are designed to serve (to serve children, to serve men). They hardly have the privilege to enjoy their own bodies, since male dominated society makes us believe that our own pleasure resides in comforting others.

My name is Rinat Schnadower, a selfish, playful, hedonistic, un-nurturing female photographer and performance artist, and for the last 2 years, I have been dealing with the question: WHY?

 

                           

 

What is “Play” all about?

My upcoming exhibition, “Play”, is a result of this intensive process. A series of works that deal mainly with the female body – with my own body –, since there is nothing like self-portraiture to deconstruct myself into parent and child, dominator and dominated (photographer and model) and engage in a dual role play where I play both parts.

As you must have already guessed, I’m very excited about it. This first solo show is for me an opportunity to contribute to the world my unique point of view about playfulness, role play and gender, and to introduce my style that is flashy and surreal, daring and surprising and in many cases, provocative, as some critics say. I must admit I take it as a compliment: provoking people to feel or to think nowadays, isn’t an easy task.

  

                              

 

 

 

            

 

 What I Need & What You Get

In order to make my exhibition happen, I need 5,000 dollars.

  • 15 prints (50*70 to 100*70 cm):$ 1,500
  • Framings: $1,500
  • Catalogue (design and prints):$ 1,500
  • Perks production: 500$                                          

 

Now, for those of you who wonder what you get out of your contribution (apart from the satisfaction of supporting avant-garde art that will surely become classical soon), my answer is: it can be either a personal mention in my artist’s page on Facebook, a publication of your own playful self-portrait in my personal lab or my art blog and even an original piece from a numbered series (limited editions), it all depends on your budget, of course.

 

                           

 

Other Ways You Can be part of “Play”

I am well conscious not everyone can contribute to my exhibition with money. But there are other ways to help too:

  • Visit my art lab at: http://rinatslab.blogspot.co.il and if you like it, LIKE it.
  • Like my artist’s page on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Rinat-Schnadower-Art/219027768242975
  • And of course: spread the word, for we all want so this show can actually happen!

 

               

 

                                                   

 

                 

 

Let’s get serious: some facts about myself:

  • I was born in Mexico City (1978), live and work in Tel Aviv, Israel
  • I have a BA in combined arts from Tel Aviv University, and I studied photography in Camera Obscura School of Arts, Tel Aviv
  • I am a member of P8 Gallery, a communal gallery where art is done for the sake of art (a communal gallery means: a nonprofit organization where the members create, curate, do the PR, design the invitations for the exhibitions, paint the walls before and after each exhibition, clean the place, pay the rent and in exchange for all that, get total creative freedom and receive full retribution for their sales.)
  • You can look through my full art resume at:

 

http://www.p8gallery.net/#!Rinat Shnadower|c10a0

 

THANK YOU IN ADVANCE, I’M LOOKING FORWARD TO RETRIBUTE!

story:
NOTICE

OUR GOAL AMOUNT HAS BEEN REDUCED TO US$6,000/S$8,000!

About the Affair

Part symposium, part art festival — otherwise, a gathering — A Weekend Affair is set to occur in June, 2019. The year marks the 200th year of Singapore’s marriage to her colonial legacies, which have manifested in myriad ways, from the pristinely-kept barracks turned art gallery clusters, to socio-militarised policymaking and the “Raffles-Singapore” brand. Taking on the theme of ‘an affair’, what we seek is a deviation from this union through, on one hand, a reinvestigation of our sociopolitical history, and on the other, a regeneration of theory on how we might (re)negotiate our relationship with coloniality&/capitalism  — away from the infamous “divide and rule” — and into a shared future.

It is therefore vital to recognise the need to go beyond this relationship with coloniality; to see that it extends to unravel the threads of relation that weave the complex contemporary condition of capitalism, characterised by exhaustions, depression, alienation, and the sense of perpetual crises and precariousness. Hence, the question is then one of departure: how do we begin to disentangle from a relationship 200 years in the making, and how do we reinvent or forge a new relationship through a different form of currency or exchange? How do we care for one another in this condition? If an uprising is unimaginable, how does one be covert?

As an independent initiative, A Weekend Affair is also, in some ways, a purposeful deviation from practised methods of finding funding in the arts, and an exercise in alternative fundraising. We fully acknowledge that what we are trying to do here is ambitious to say the least, and is an undertaking that requires the activation of an entire network of accomplices, alliances, and affinities. Through this Indiegogo campaign, we humbly ask for you to take a leap of faith with us, and lend your support that will be vital in helping us to realize the Weekend in June 2019. 

About Us

As A Weekend Affair is an initiative for the arts community and the public at large, it has no employable team members but comprises of some committed yet fluid and amazing people who are contributing in various ways, each of their own capacities; Wong Bing Hao, Shona Findlay, Mike H.J. Chang, Godwin Koay, and a few others! While the initiative is generally co-led by art practitioners Wayne Lim and Soh Kay Min, our design and visual identity is spearheaded by Pixie Tan, and we have Seet Yun Teng, our lovely volunteer.

The Weekend

Meant to be more than just an intimate gathering of peoples and communities, and drawing from the signature events of art and academia — the festival and the symposium — A Weekend Affair aims to bring about a sharing of knowledge through theory and different forms of (art) practice, and turning ideas into reality through practice. The ‘presentations’ will happen on June 1-2, 2019, at a chalet located at the historically loaded Changi-Loyang part of Singapore. 

Aside from the programme line-up that will come out of proposals received from the open call, parallel collateral projects with long-term collaborators of The Affair will also happen concurrently during the weekend itself. There will be time for lunches and breaks in between; discussion sessions will happen at the end, after dinner time on both days. Definitely, lots of hanging out! 

As aforementioned, A Weekend Affair is essentially a gathering, a space to unwind; for (self-)care, love and intimacy. Come with friends; get soaked in (art) theory, get a massage, walk on the beach, read or, for the BBQ — that is up to you! 

We are pleased to announce the results of our open call, which will be part of Main Program of The Weekend! A Weekend Affair presents: Zhiyi Cao, Kevin Chua, Stephanie Dogfoot, Vimal Kumar, Loo Zihan, Jaxton Su & Chen Jiexiao, Berny Tan and Johann Yamin. Hailing from Tokyo, New York, and Bangkok, we have Hibiki Mizuno, Amelyn Ng and Pitchaya Ngamcharoen.

Intent

Without too much oversimplification, the purpose of A Weekend Affair is more than just providing a platform for ideas to brew; it also aims to spur discussion through interdisciplinary (art) practices. Through our thematics (mentioned above) and our Weekend program (consisting of the open call and collateral events), we are asking for a genuine get-together, a safe — albeit temporary — space to turn affinities into action(s); connection(s) into care; to discuss about difficult things, but also to speak simply, and be unrestrained. We are asking you to seek to deviate, but not to disacknowledge; to refuse but not to rebel. 

All in all, A Weekend Affair suggests lush intimacy, passion, and care, but at the same time, it is also covert, and perhaps (most importantly) fugitive and unregulated. To find out more about the theoretical interests behind A Weekend Affair, please click here: https://aweekendaffair.info/About 

Where is the money going?

A Weekend Affair works within strict principles and grounds with regards to its conceptual framework. Committing to the hope of a genuinely shared future — one against popular narratives and nationalist strategies — we remain steadfast in our commitment to A Weekend Affair as a bottom-up and non-profit initiative. Our team has donated their time and labour (and money) in planning and organising this event, not to mention the input of many other contributors, mentors, and friends.

At the same time, we firmly believe in paid creative labour and its importance in sustaining a healthy art community not reliant on exploitation and precarious labour conditions. Your money would firstly go into providing a small fee to all presenters during the Weekend. Secondly, it will fund the event operational costs for the Weekend itself (June 2019), including venue costs, logistics, and food.

In addition to the Weekend, there will be three lead-up events, Rendezvous I, II and III. The first Rendezvous will see the launch of this crowdfunding campaign at Telok Ayer Arts Club, the second being a collaboration with Bras Basah Open: School of Theory and Philosophy (BBO) in the form of the collective’s signature TheoryFILM format at The Substation on March 31, 2019 (click here to see our Facebook event page and here to get your tickets)! 

*Details regarding the third rendezvous will be announced in time. It should tentatively be a week before The Weekend, on May 25, 2019.*

We are working towards putting together a mini-publication, Unfaithful to the System, that runs along the thematics of A Weekend Affair, and will address the complex condition of contemporary colonial-capitalism that we seek to disentangle from. However, due to overwhelming work involving the planning or A Weekend Affair, we have decided to make publication a post-Affair matter. Please do not feel discouraged from claiming this perk, because we are reworking our publication timeline at the moment, and still aiming to publish it by the end of this year!

Here is the breakdown of estimated operational costs for A Weekend Affair:

Note: We have cut down significantly (between 50-70%) on our budget/operational costs to reflect the bare necessities of what’s needed for A Weekend Affair to go on. Budget costs for the Publication will be moved to future funding after the Weekend – however, we’re still accepting Indiegogo perk claims for the Publication, which will be produced in the near future.

Venue

S$1,694.88 - A Weekend Affair (on June 1-2, 2019)

S$0 - Rendezvous I, II & III (although a significant amount has been contributed towards Rendezvous I, we are doing Rendezvous II rent-free at The Substation, and we aim to make Rendezvous III a zero-expense teaser too)

Support

S$500 - Fees to Open Call Presenters during A Weekend Affair 

S$450 - Flights support

Printing & Media

S$570 - Stickers, leaflets, posters, etc.

S$179.12 - Website, media, etc.

Other Operations & Installations

S$ $1,500 - Installations (during The Weekend), curatorial budget

S$500 - Logistics, food & beverages

#supporttheaffair perks

We deeply value your support, and we're excited to provide some perks that you can look forward to receiving:

  • AWKNDAFFR stickers

We are the sticky sort! Our most economically-friendly perk, put together neatly by our co-cheater and designer, Pixie Tan. Each sheet of sticker has 6 of our various logos and blobs, at only S$12!

​

  • Raffle, not Raffles Lottery Ticket

Conceived with the kindest help of artist Mike HJ Chang, Raffles, not Raffles is an art lottery comprising of artwork donations made by great artists (this list is expected to grow to a final list of 20 artists/artworks for the pool), who are similarly dedicated in helping A Weekend Affair come to realisation. As the main perk on our Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign, we hope to generate the interests of supporters by giving them a chance to own one of these artworks! 200 tickets are available, with each at S$48 (including our stickers), and obviously, the more tickets you have, the higher your chances of bringing home an artwork/having an artwork shipped to you, by one of our participating artists.

The draw of the lottery will happen on The Weekend in June, 2019.

Below are some works by the generous artists:

 

Mike H. J. Chang

The Retrograde Head

Watercolour on paper

60 x 52 cm

2017

Hilmi Johandi

Untitled (spacewheel)

Digital print on Ilford cotton rag paper

57 cm x 42 cm

2018

 

  • Publication Unfaithful to the System: an Anthology Necessarily about Singapore (working title)

Alongside A Weekend Affair, Unfaithful to the System is the working title of the publication that we have initially hoped to roll out before The Weekend. The publication will be a roughly 100-page, 10-12 literary compilation necessarily about the complex condition of contemporary colonial-capitalism that we seek to disentangle from, which will also run along with the thematics of A Weekend Affair. With our current quotation, each publication is at S$28.

*Due to the scale of this scandalous affair (pun intended), we have decided to make our publication a post-Affair matter now. This publication is offered as a perk and will be produced and delivered after the Affair.

  • The Hibiscus Spa and Wellness by Divaagar

Tired of going through the motions of urban living? Treat yourselves at The Hibiscus: Spa and Wellness!

Conceived through the secrets of the rainforests of South East Asia, The Hibiscus offers the ultimate pampering experience featuring holistic treatments for complete physical, mental and spiritual renewal.

Sit back and relax as our therapists welcome you with a soothing foot bath and massage. Leave the cares of the world behind as you enjoy a cup of our specially concocted jamu, enjoyed best paired with a unique floral facial!

Treatments start from a donation of $26 and above.

Come, indulge yourselves.

A performance by Divaagar, beyond performing the functions of an orientalized/exoticized spa; it aims to provide services of care and decolonial relief, from one’s body and mind by serving ayurvedic varieties of jamu, ancient traditional skincare treatments and foot reflexology services, that relieves you of what ails you in modern Singapore.

Three types of treatments:

  1. Simple Pleasures (20 minutes): Massage session — S$26
  2. Exuberance (30 minutes): Massage session + Full treatment — S$44
  3. Night Magic (50 minutes): Massage session + Full treatment (extra intensive) — S$82

How else can I help?

Of course, support can also come in non-monetary form. If you can't contribute, please share this Indiegogo page and spread the word about the campaign and A Weekend Affair!

We welcome other forms of support, whether if it's helping out as we come closer to the weekend, suggestions pertaining to our #aweekendmonthly reading list, or help in securing our venue in Changi (if you already have a membership/wish to donate the S$300 membership fee for us). 

We sincerely hope that this gathering is more than a BBQ session, but a beginning of a community of friends/practitioners, that is willing to take a step further in disentangling, and working on ways to deviate.

To straying, loving, deviating, and learning: please #supporttheaffair!

Our team has donated their time and labour (and money) in planning and organising this event, not to mention the input of many other contributors, mentors, and friends.
At the same time, we firmly believe in paid creative labour and its importance in sustaining a healthy art community not reliant on exploitation and precarious labour conditions. Your money would firstly go into providing a small fee to all presenters during the Weekend. Secondly, it will fund the event operational costs for the Weekend itself (June 2019), including venue costs, logistics, and food.
In addition to the Weekend, there will be three lead-up events, Rendezvous I, II and III. The first Rendezvous will see the launch of this crowdfunding campaign at Telok Ayer Arts Club, the second being a collaboration with Bras Basah Open: School of Theory and Philosophy (BBO) in the form of the collective’s signature TheoryFILM format at The Substation on March 31, 2019 (click here to see our Facebook event page and here to get your tickets)! 
*Details regarding the third rendezvous will be announced in time. It should tentatively be a week before The Weekend, on May 25, 2019.*
We are working towards putting together a mini-publication, Unfaithful to the System, that runs along the thematics of A Weekend Affair, and will address the complex condition of contemporary colonial-capitalism that we seek to disentangle from. However, due to overwhelming work involving the planning or A Weekend Affair, we have decided to make publication a post-Affair matter. Please do not feel discouraged from claiming this perk, because we are reworking our publication timeline at the moment, and still aiming to publish it by the end of this year!
Here is the breakdown of estimated operational costs for A Weekend Affair:
Note: We have cut down significantly (between 50-70%) on our budget/operational costs to reflect the bare necessities of what’s needed for A Weekend Affair to go on. Budget costs for the Publication will be moved to future funding after the Weekend – however, we’re still accepting Indiegogo perk claims for the Publication, which will be produced in the near future.
Venue
S$1,694.88 - A Weekend Affair (on June 1-2, 2019)
S$0 - Rendezvous I, II & III (although a significant amount has been contributed towards Rendezvous I, we are doing Rendezvous II rent-free at The Substation, and we aim to make Rendezvous III a zero-expense teaser too)
Support
S$500 - Fees to Open Call Presenters during A Weekend Affair 
S$450 - Flights support
Printing & Media
S$570 - Stickers, leaflets, posters, etc.
S$179.12 - Website, media, etc.
Other Operations & Installations
S$ $1,500 - Installations (during The Weekend), curatorial budget
S$500 - Logistics, food & beverages
#supporttheaffair perks
We deeply value your support, and we're excited to provide some perks that you can look forward to receiving:

AWKNDAFFR stickers
We are the sticky sort! Our most economically-friendly perk, put together neatly by our co-cheater and designer, Pixie Tan. Each sheet of sticker has 6 of our various logos and blobs, at only S$12!
​

Raffle, not Raffles Lottery Ticket
Conceived with the kindest help of artist Mike HJ Chang, Raffles, not Raffles is an art lottery comprising of artwork donations made by great artists (this list is expected to grow to a final list of 20 artists/artworks for the pool), who are similarly dedicated in helping A Weekend Affair come to realisation. As the main perk on our Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign, we hope to generate the interests of supporters by giving them a chance to own one of these artworks! 200 tickets are available, with each at S$48 (including our stickers), and obviously, the more tickets you have, the higher your chances of bringing home an artwork/having an artwork shipped to you, by one of our participating artists.
The draw of the lottery will happen on The Weekend in June, 2019.
Below are some works by the generous artists:
 
Mike H. J. Chang

The Retrograde Head
Watercolour on paper
60 x 52 cm
2017
Hilmi Johandi

Untitled (spacewheel)
Digital print on Ilford cotton rag paper
57 cm x 42 cm
2018
 

Publication Unfaithful to the System: an Anthology Necessarily about Singapore (working title)
Alongside A Weekend Affair, Unfaithful to the System is the working title of the publication that we have initially hoped to roll out before The Weekend. The publication will be a roughly 100-page, 10-12 literary compilation necessarily about the complex condition of contemporary colonial-capitalism that we seek to disentangle from, which will also run along with the thematics of A Weekend Affair. With our current quotation, each publication is at S$28.
*Due to the scale of this scandalous affair (pun intended), we have decided to make our publication a post-Affair matter now. This publication is offered as a perk and will be produced and delivered after the Affair.


The Hibiscus Spa and Wellness by Divaagar
Tired of going through the motions of urban living? Treat yourselves at The Hibiscus: Spa and Wellness!
Conceived through the secrets of the rainforests of South East Asia, The Hibiscus offers the ultimate pampering experience featuring holistic treatments for complete physical, mental and spiritual renewal.
Sit back and relax as our therapists welcome you with a soothing foot bath and massage. Leave the cares of the world behind as you enjoy a cup of our specially concocted jamu, enjoyed best paired with a unique floral facial!
Treatments start from a donation of $26 and above.
Come, indulge yourselves.
A performance by Divaagar, beyond performing the functions of an orientalized/exoticized spa; it aims to provide services of care and decolonial relief, from one’s body and mind by serving ayurvedic varieties of jamu, ancient traditional skincare treatments and foot reflexology services, that relieves you of what ails you in modern Singapore.
Three types of treatments:

Simple Pleasures (20 minutes): Massage session — S$26
Exuberance (30 minutes): Massage session + Full treatment — S$44
Night Magic (50 minutes): Massage session + Full treatment (extra intensive) — S$82

How else can I help?
Of course, support can also come in non-monetary form. If you can't contribute, please share this Indiegogo page and spread the word about the campaign and A Weekend Affair!

We welcome other forms of support, whether if it's helping out as we come closer to the weekend, suggestions pertaining to our #aweekendmonthly reading list, or help in securing our venue in Changi (if you already have a membership/wish to donate the S$300 membership fee for us). 
We sincerely hope that this gathering is more than a BBQ session, but a beginning of a community of friends/practitioners, that is willing to take a step further in disentangling, and working on ways to deviate.To straying, loving, deviating, and learning: please #supporttheaffair!

story:
Hello all!

I will be part of a gallery exhibit at The Sprinkler Factory in Worcester, MA coming up this June where I will be showing NEW abstract-expressionist watercolors.

You may know me from poetry slam (or poetry audiences), but I got my BFA in painting from The University of Massachusetts, Amherst, back in the twentieth century. I make compositions based on astronomical and biological forms and the physical characteristics of paint. I use professional-quality paint and paper.

One characteristic of watercolors is that they are delicate, both physically and in response to uv light, so they really need to be archivally framed to be displayed.

I’ve found a service that builds frames from archival materials and museum-grade uv acrylic. I’ve used them before and they do good work. It’s reasonably priced, but not cheap. So, I’m asking for your help to allow me to present this work properly. My goal is to have ten 29" x 18" framed watercolors ready for the show.

All pledgers will be invited to a private house showing of the work before it is hung in the gallery, with snacks and live music.

story:
Nopal Cultural Center

Nopal was founded by two Indianapolis culturists whose common goal is to promote the music and art scene in a way which would bring crowds of diverse people together. We have been around for almost two years now and have organized many events which did just that.

This fall we are organizing our second annual Day De Los Muertos event, our take on Dia de Muertos (Day of the Dead) which brings together many creative movers and shakers in Indy's community. The result is an enchanting community event which meshes tradition with contemporary takes from all our contributors.

This event is highly important to us because it involves many volunteers from different racial backgrounds. Co-founder Daniel Del Real has stated "When we bring the best of each of our cultures together, we create something unique and beautiful." This is exactly what we are aiming to do and need your help to achieve.

The contributions from this campaign will help us create an event which will honor both the tradition of Day of the Dead and how we as a diverse and contemporary society are making it our own today. To be able to express that to the community is highly valuable because it creates a stronger appreciation for creativity and culture.


Day De Los Muertos

Why Day De Los Muertos? Why not Day of the Dead or Dia de los Muertos?

Because we want to create an environment which allows both Latino and Non-Latino individuals to feel like they are welcome and can appreciate this event. Our events are always Spanglish oriented. They say there's two sides to every story, we want to show you both the traditional story and the contemporary interpretation, we will do that by telling it to you in a way which is universally understood through English and Spanish language programming.


What we need to tell that story

When we decided to host our own Day of the Dead celebration last year, we tossed around a lot of ideas to incorporate both traditional, transitional, and contemporary aspects of this holiday. With limited funding we were forced to choose only a few which we felt best told the story.

This time we want to implement more ideas and tell a larger story.

We need funding to cover the costs associated with the three week long exhibition and celebration day. Although we have many volunteers to help build and put together the exhibition, we need funds to cover the costs of supplies. Here's what we need:

  • Lumber, hardware, paint, and objects to construct the altar structures
  • Colored paper, tissue paper, and miscellaneous art supplies
  • Traditional costumes for our Catrinas and Catrines to wear
  • Makeup, hair spray and other beauty products for the Catrinas, and Catrines
  • Fabrics, accessories, and supplies to create items which cannot be sourced
  • Funds to cover the costs to print our posters, flyers and programs. We need to get the word out!
  • Lights, stands, and speakers which we will use on the day of our celebration
  • Photography and videography to document our event
  • Because we believe in supporting our artists, we would like to provide stipends to all the creative individuals involved with building altars, designing hairdos, makeup, and performers.

Our offerings to you. Gracias!

Nopal Cultural Center volunteers have been hard at work creating different offerings for you in exchange for your generous contributions:

The Day De Los Muertos sticker measures 3" in diameter. Slap them around anywhere to show your Day of the Dead pride! They are featured in the "Pegajoso" contribution level.

These brooches are hand painted by Nopal Cultural Center artists and come in different sizes and colors. Different brooches are rewarded for different levels of contribution under "Chiquita," "Mediana," and "Grande." Or you could get the entire collection under the "Colección" and "Colección Doz" contribution levels.


Cempasúchil is the official flower of Day of the Dead. When you contribute for our "Cempasúchil" perk, you will get a paper cempasúchil kit which makes a dozen flowers for you to incorporate into your own altars. Gather the family and watch our tutorial to create your own bouquet.


Nopal community artist Carlos Torres Cazares designed this t-shirt for our contributors. The design was hand carved and hand printed onto each t-shirt and ready for our "Camiseta" contributors.


This altar by Daniel Del Real was created last year for our celebration. We are offering a similar crate style altar to our contributors under the "Ofrenda" perk. We will do our best to create an altar which reflects the life of your dearly departed loved one. It will be displayed in the main altar inside the exhibition hall, and you will be able to keep it after the exhibition closes.


This portrait of Nopal Cultural Center's mascot, Taquito De Frijol was painted by Mary E. Mindiola. She will paint a portrait of your pet as a perk for your contribution. Find it under the "Mascota" contribution level.


Amber and Esteban Martinez form the group Meztli. They are on board to offer you a private performance as a reward for your contribution. Find the perk titled "Musica" for more information.


You can also help this way...

If you are unable to contribute financially, you can still help us by spreading the word about our campaign. Please share our campaign in social media and among your friends. We really appreciate it. Also, you can help by volunteering. Feel free to contact us at nopalindy@gmail.com regarding volunteer opportunities. We could use more hands. Lastly, You could help us by spreading the word about our event. We have created a Facebook event page (click on the Facebook logo below), we want to reach out to as many people as we can who want to learn about this beautiful holiday. Thank you!

Your contribution is tax-deductible as a gift to Big Car, the fiscal sponsor for this project.  Your contribution is restricted to this project of Nopal Cultural Center.

story:
Dawn's Summary

I write this message for my friends and family. I am so close to bringing forth my handmade jewelry company Simple Creations but I need some help. Most of you know that I am having health complications and have been out of work for several months. Expenses are pilling up, and all though I am trying my best to remain strong and positive, I am struggling to make ends meet. Over the past two years handcrafting earrings, necklaces, and photo frames has given me an reassuring outlet. When i create I am at peace and filled with joy and hope. 

I hope to be able create a website, online store, and incorporate my business. Taking these professional steps will make it easier for me to obtain the licensing and permits necessary to sell my work on a bigger platform. 

My original goal is only $300 but with Indegogo the minimum amount you can crowd fund for is $500. I really would appreciate all donations and be forever grateful to you all. 

What I Need What You Get 

•Incorporate Simple Creations

•Buy a Simple domain name
•Create a website with Simple monthly hosting

What You Get

• Handcrafted gifts for your appreciated donations.

story:
The Phoenix is a potent symbol of what Burning Man means to us and so many others. Burning Man is both cyclical and uniquely of the moment. In this way, the Phoenix both burns away uniquely, yet remains to be rebuilt and burned again. The piece is both performative and physically permanent. It is a symbol of rebirth and renewal.

The Phoenix Rising will be an 18 foot steel bird made of 1.25" corten steel rod. Once the steel sculpture is finished it will be clad using reclaimed and drift wood creating a 20 foot bird. The art piece will then be burned on the playa at the 2017 Burning Man Festival. 

27 inch copper mock up of the Phoenix Rising by Nicholas Palmer

27 inch wooden mock up of the Phoenix Rising 



3D mockup of the 18 foot steel bird done by Tim Hart  

Please help Friends of a Feather get this art piece to the playa!

The money raised during this fundraiser will go to:

Metal $3,200

Corten solid rod of 1 ¼”x320’ ( $1450)

Corten Sheet ¼’’ ($500)

Base frame Corten solid rod 2’’x 40’ ($300)

Welding consumables $650

Nuts and bolts ($300)

Wood  $Free

Driftwood  (day at the beach, but I am always collecting nice driftwood when I see it)

Manzanita (Martin’s Property)

Cutoffs from Mel

Pallets (easy to find)

Scott said he can start saving tons of good wood from his worksites

Cedar shakes could be cool to do parts of the body

Electricity and lighting $500

Generator (sure we can source a small 2000 for the week within our contacts)

Gas - $200

RGB LED Cannons - $300

Extension cords ( should have lots between our crew)

Timers

Transportation $300

Gas money - $300

The Burn $820

Fabric and fuel ($20)

Ground cover for the burn( do we supply or Burning Man) decomposed granite ($500)

Safety Crew (Fire extinguishers/vests) $300

Hardware $600

3 ½ “ T25 - $200

Lag Bolts - $150

Brad Nails $150

Anchors $100

Specialty Installation $300

Generator- personal gear

Gas $100

Flood lights $ 200

 

Total: $5720


If we do not meet our goal of $5000 the Phoenix Rising construction will continue as planned and other fund raising efforts will be put in place.  

If we exceed of goal of $5000 this will go towards embellishing the metal Phoenix.

Friends of a Feather,  is grateful to be building the Phoenix Rising at the Generator in Reno, Nevada. The Generator is a collective that allows artists a workspace and tools to achieve his/her goals operating under the same principals as Burning Man.

Thank you for taking your time to check out our fundraiser. There are more ways to help than just monetarily:

Please share our page with your friends!
Like us on Facebook: 
https://www.facebook.com/Phoenixrising240/ 
Volunteers of all skill levels are also welcome to come down to help at the Generator.
If you will be at the 2017 Burning Man we will be looking for volunteers for the burn perimeter as well as post burn for clean up.   

Thanks again!

Love, 

Friends of a Feather

story:
OUR BEGINNINGS:
The concept of IntoWishin’ Arts started with a WORK OF ART, an EVENT, and a SIGN!

Our 22 year-old son, Henry was born with developmental disabilities. When he was a Sophomore in high school, his art teacher sent a WORK OF ART into a statewide art competition. It was this portrait of his dog Maizy, and he won first place! Henry went on to create lots of other pretty cool artwork in high school too! All the way up until he graduated.

And that’s the EVENT we are talking about. It was right about that time that Henry, his Mom and I figured out that the job world is MUCH different from school for people like Henry. It’s better than decades ago, but the jobs offered to Henry and his friends with abilities like his were less than imaginative. That’s when we were given a SIGN!

We drove by a fairly common disabilities parking sign one day at our local grocery store and our five year old son, Henry's brother shouted from the back seat…“Dad, is this the place where people with possibilities park?”

“POSS-ABILITIES”    ...and yes, we purposefully spelled it that way.  :-)

That was the BIG IDEA that pulled the spirit of IntoWishin’ Arts all together.

We believe every human being is a broad spectrum of possABILITIES. Our company is all about viewing people for what they are capable of, naturally and joyfully, and then joining our possABILITIES together to great a stronger community.

WHY US, WHY ME, & WHY NOW?
I am a father of a 22 year-old son with disabilities, so I intimately know the need for more creative career solutions that lead to independence for adults with disabilities. 

Integration into the community and work training programs for adults with disabilities have come a long way in my lifetime, but I think we can do better. I believe we are on the verge of a disruption in the public’ paradigm of how much people with disabilities can contribute to the goodness of our world. The current rate of full-time employment for people with disabilities nationally is around 33%, so this population needs innovative ideas, and investment.

My professional career spans three decades starting in advertising graphic design, package and retail design, and into product development. In this capacity, I worked with dozens of clients in the Fortune 500 and top 100 CPG’s in the United States to create effective packaging, point of sale solutions, and products.

I want to use my experience and talents to go beyond helping corporations, to help some very special people discover, and find success in their creative abilities. My combined graphic design, marketing, sales and business leadership skill set and experiences have prepared me to lead this project.

We know that there are thousands more artists out there in the world just like my son who could be gaining independence and making a living from their creative abilities and talents. These are the people we want to find and help with IntoWishin’ Arts.

OUR GOAL & OUR NEEDS

We are attempting to raise $36,000. When you help us get to our funding goal, as a founding member of IntoWishin' Arts your contribution will help fund the following six expenses:

1.) Outreach communication to adults with disabilities, and the nonprofit organizations who serve them, so we can inform more of them about us, our workshop, and product selling opportunities.

2.) Art workshops for adults with disabilities to create art and design.

3.) Art supplies for our workshops

4.) Paying dedicated staff, art teachers and mentors to facilitate IntoWishin’ Arts workshops.

5.) Expenses associated with building our very first e-commerce t-shirt and apparel store where all of the designs will be inspired and created by adults with disabilities.

6.) Legal and accounting fees associated with creating art, copyright law, and protecting trademarks on behalf of our artists.

OUR COMPANY & GIVING CULTURE
We are a for-profit e-commerce business with a social mission to help artists with disabilities earn an income from their art and gain greater financial independence. We will pay artists above-industry royalties for each product sold, and artists will maintain their original copyright. Our mission also includes partnerships with nonprofits that already serve adults with disabilities. IntoWishin' Arts will also donate 10% of annual profits above and beyond royalties paid to artists with disabilities to our non-profit partners to create even more art creation activities. 

We intend to earn B-Corp status to provide the community important transparency about our business practices.  

OUR GROWTH PLANS
The plans are to crowd-fund to launch more creative workshops over the first six months of 2018. We’ll prove the concept in our local market of Appleton and Green Bay, Wisconsin to work out the bugs and bring the concept to other US markets

WAYS YOU CAN HELP
We will be launching via IndieGogo, so we need interested parties to invest in our start-up, share our campaign, and help us spread awareness of our existence to investors, nonprofits servicing the disabled population, arts educators, and disabled adults around the entire US.

Please SHARE this campaign directly by email, social media, blogs, and IndieGogo’s sharing tools.

Our SUCCESS depends on YOU!

Thank you!

*NOTE: All Thank You Package shipments, including  charitableGift Certificate Packages will become available in January 2018. After a donation is made, we will contact you to confirm your product preferences, colors, sizes, etc. Confirmation emails will be sent to keep you informed of our progress and anticipated delivery dates. All thank you gifts include FREE GROUND SHIPPING and handling in the US, with options to expedite, or send internationally.
story_txt: OUR BEGINNINGS:The concept of IntoWishin’ Arts started with a WORK OF ART, an EVENT, and a SIGN!Our 22 year-old son, Henry was born with developmental disabilities. When he was a Sophomore in high school, his art teacher sent a WORK OF ART into a statewide art competition. It was this portrait of his dog Maizy, and he won first place! Henry went on to create lots of other pretty cool artwork in high school too! All the way up until he graduated.And that’s the EVENT we are talking about. It was right about that time that Henry, his Mom and I figured out that the job world is MUCH different from school for people like Henry. It’s better than decades ago, but the jobs offered to Henry and his friends with abilities like his were less than imaginative. That’s when we were given a SIGN!We drove by a fairly common disabilities parking sign one day at our local grocery store and our five year old son, Henry's brother shouted from the back seat…“Dad, is this the place where people with possibilities park?”“POSS-ABILITIES”    ...and yes, we purposefully spelled it that way.  :-)That was the BIG IDEA that pulled the spirit of IntoWishin’ Arts all together.We believe every human being is a broad spectrum of possABILITIES. Our company is all about viewing people for what they are capable of, naturally and joyfully, and then joining our possABILITIES together to great a stronger community.WHY US, WHY ME, & WHY NOW?I am a father of a 22 year-old son with disabilities, so I intimately know the need for more creative career solutions that lead to independence for adults with disabilities. Integration into the community and work training programs for adults with disabilities have come a long way in my lifetime, but I think we can do better. I believe we are on the verge of a disruption in the public’ paradigm of how much people with disabilities can contribute to the goodness of our world. The current rate of full-time employment for people with disabilities nationally is around 33%, so this population needs innovative ideas, and investment.My professional career spans three decades starting in advertising graphic design, package and retail design, and into product development. In this capacity, I worked with dozens of clients in the Fortune 500 and top 100 CPG’s in the United States to create effective packaging, point of sale solutions, and products.I want to use my experience and talents to go beyond helping corporations, to help some very special people discover, and find success in their creative abilities. My combined graphic design, marketing, sales and business leadership skill set and experiences have prepared me to lead this project.We know that there are thousands more artists out there in the world just like my son who could be gaining independence and making a living from their creative abilities and talents. These are the people we want to find and help with IntoWishin’ Arts.OUR GOAL & OUR NEEDSWe are attempting to raise $36,000. When you help us get to our funding goal, as a founding member of IntoWishin' Arts your contribution will help fund the following six expenses:1.) Outreach communication to adults with disabilities, and the nonprofit organizations who serve them, so we can inform more of them about us, our workshop, and product selling opportunities.2.) Art workshops for adults with disabilities to create art and design.3.) Art supplies for our workshops4.) Paying dedicated staff, art teachers and mentors to facilitate IntoWishin’ Arts workshops.5.) Expenses associated with building our very first e-commerce t-shirt and apparel store where all of the designs will be inspired and created by adults with disabilities.6.) Legal and accounting fees associated with creating art, copyright law, and protecting trademarks on behalf of our artists.OUR COMPANY & GIVING CULTUREWe are a for-profit e-commerce business with a social mission to help artists with disabilities earn an income from their art and gain greater financial independence. We will pay artists above-industry royalties for each product sold, and artists will maintain their original copyright. Our mission also includes partnerships with nonprofits that already serve adults with disabilities. IntoWishin' Arts will also donate 10% of annual profits above and beyond royalties paid to artists with disabilities to our non-profit partners to create even more art creation activities. We intend to earn B-Corp status to provide the community important transparency about our business practices.  OUR GROWTH PLANSThe plans are to crowd-fund to launch more creative workshops over the first six months of 2018. We’ll prove the concept in our local market of Appleton and Green Bay, Wisconsin to work out the bugs and bring the concept to other US marketsWAYS YOU CAN HELPWe will be launching via IndieGogo, so we need interested parties to invest in our start-up, share our campaign, and help us spread awareness of our existence to investors, nonprofits servicing the disabled population, arts educators, and disabled adults around the entire US.Please SHARE this campaign directly by email, social media, blogs, and IndieGogo’s sharing tools.Our SUCCESS depends on YOU!Thank you!*NOTE: All Thank You Package shipments, including  charitableGift Certificate Packages will become available in January 2018. After a donation is made, we will contact you to confirm your product preferences, colors, sizes, etc. Confirmation emails will be sent to keep you informed of our progress and anticipated delivery dates. All thank you gifts include FREE GROUND SHIPPING and handling in the US, with options to expedite, or send internationally.

story:
Qué es Kino Tarragonik


Kino Tarragonik es el primer festival audiovisual de carácter colaborativo de Cataluña, con un formato único: 25 participantes deben realizar 5 cortometrajes en un tiempo límite de 54h. 

El festival es el evento más importante de la entidad sin ánimo de lucro Tarragonik, una asociación que es el resultado de la iniciativa de dos jóvenes emprendedoras que comparten su pasión por el mundo audiovisual y el arte: Priscila Gómez y Eli Gilart, respaldadas por un equipo de colaboradores.

Tras varios años trabajando en distintos proyectos deciden unir esfuerzos para abrir una nueva puerta a los profesionales del sector audiovisual creando esta entidad con la que construir una comunidad profesional, fomentar el desarrollo y promoción de sus miembros y colaboradores mediante actividades y formación continuada y promover la cultura local a través de productos audiovisuales.


Lugar: Tarragona y Delta de l'Ebre.

Fechas: Del 1 al 3 de julio de 2016

Más información: https://www.facebook.com/kino.tarragonik 

 

Qué necesitamos

 

Kino Tarragonik es de carácter colaborativo, de forma que los 5 cortometrajes que se desarrollen en los 3 días que dura el festival serán única y exclusivamente resultado del esfuerzo de los participantes, con el apoyo y participación del equipo organizativo. 

Aunque los participantes aportan la parte necesaria a nivel de equipo técnico (cámaras, trípodes, iluminación, maquillaje, etc.) queremos proporcionarles todos los materiales y facilidades que necesitan para sacar adelante cada uno de los proyectos, de forma que no deban costearlo ellos. 

Además queremos promocionar el festival a nivel local tanto a nivel educativo (Escuelas de Audiovisual y Cine, Escuelas de Arte) y mediático para poder garantizar su viabilidad y su continuidad para futuras ediciones. 
Por ello, los fondos recaudados en esta campaña serán destinados únicamente a los materiales y medios esenciales para la poder desarrollar el festival y sus actividades paralelas con éxito, entre ellos: 
     
  • 200 unidades de agua embotellada para los participantes.
  • 30 lanyards y tarjetas identificativas del festival para participantes y organización.
  • Producción de material promocional (bolsas de tela).
  • 2 botiquines.
  • Impresión de cartelería.
  • Ayuda para transporte, alojamiento y comidas.
  • Seguro para equipos y personas. 
 

Impacto

 
Se publicarán los cortometrajes de esta primera edición del festival en los canales oficiales del Kino Tarragonik, incluyendo la web oficial www.tarragonik.wordpress.com , la página oficial de Facebook, Twitter e Instagram.   
 

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

 

Si no puedes hacer una aportación económica, no significa que no puedas ayudarnos:

     
  • Difunde esta campaña en tus redes sociales. Cada persona cuenta.
    •  
  • Si crees que puedes colaborar aportando alguno de los materiales o servicios que necesitamos, envía un correo a infotarragonik@gmail.com .

Agradecemos que colabores con nosotros.
¡Gracias a vuestras aportaciones la primera edición del Kino Tarragonik será todo un éxito!

story:
Summary

I am an artist, independent researcher, and educator in textiles, with a focus on embroidery and net-making.  For the past 5 years I have been traveling to study embroidery and learn techniques. I have learned Hungarian written embroidery in Transylvania, Romania, net-making and cross-stitch for mittens in Iceland, and counted cross-stitch for shirts in Oaxaca, Mexico. From 2012 - 14 I designed and manufactured products with women in Transylvania and now teach workshops in these disappearing crafts.  

What sets my craft workshops apart:  I focus on the people keeping traditions alive, their stories, the history and symbolism of their craft, as well as learning how to make a stitch or tie a knot.  My goal is for students to learn a skill, appreciate the culture, and feel a connection with Piroska in Romania or Maria in Mexico by seeing their work and hearing a bit about their lives.  

Your contribution will help me meet and learn from lace-makers, stitchers, and textile professionals in The Netherlands and Ukraine so that I can share their work and stories! 

There is so much love in handcraft, whether it warms your hands, decorates the kitchen, or commemorates a birth or death.  I want to honor the women and men who are keeping traditions alive and together, with my workshop participants, create a global community of makers united by cultural heritage skills.

I have taught workshops in the San Francisco Bay Area including the Handcraft Studio School and lectured for the Embroiderers' Guild of America.  My fine art work has been exhibited in the US and Europe.  I hold a BA from Scripps College, Claremont and an MFA in Visual Arts from Mason Gross School of the Arts, Rutgers University.

 

Your contribution will fund:

Airfare from San Francisco to Amsterdam and Amsterdam to Kiev and back.  

OBRAS artist's residency fee (apartment AND studio space for a lot less then a month's rent in the SF Bay Area!). OBRAS is located in Renkum, a city of 30,000 people on the Rhine River, a couple hours from Amsterdam by train.

Train and bus travel, budget accommodations for 3 overnight trips within the Netherlands and several day trips including Amsterdam, Tilburg, Einkhuizen, Haarlem, Rotterdam/ South Holland.  

Hostel stay in Kiev and travel/lodging in rural Western Ukraine for 4 days.  Will hire a translator.

Art Supplies: fabric (new and second-hand), thread, yarn, brass wire, brass plates, embroidery floss, thread, paper. (Before the residency I'm taking lessons with an Oakland, CA jewelry artist to make 'oorijzer', the decorative metal piece that was part of the traditional folk headdress until the 1800s. The metalwork will provide a skeleton for my sculpture.)

Lessons with an artisan in Renkum or Spakenburg: crochet for lace caps from Spakenburg or other traditional techniques.

 

The Impact

I have been awarded and successfully completed international artist's residencies in Budapest, Hungary, Blonduos, Iceland, and Oaxaca, Mexico.  I am confident that I will be to take full advantage of my residency in the Netherlands, making artwork, learning new skills, and documenting my research on Dutch textiles.  Please take a look at my Instagram account @threadwritten!  Scroll back for images from Mexico, Iceland, and my handful of trips to Transylvania, Romania.

Your contribution will fund lessons with artisans in the Netherlands and Ukraine, documentation of disappearing textile practices, and skill-building for new workshops I'll offer in the US!

 

Risks & Challenges

Travel is always an adventure with many unknowns!  Using the residency as a source of support and introduction to the local culture, it provides a stable and comfortable home base and entry into the community.  Sometimes projects shift or a new discovery changes the direction of my work, however I don't see any challenges getting in the way of having a rich experience with much to share when I return.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, share, share! Use the share buttons at the top next to the pink 'Back it' button.

Copy and paste:

Support cultural exchange, art, textile research, and new craft workshops!

ThreadWritten is going to the Netherlands! Support textiles, culture, and future workshops in the US!

Do Dutch folk costumes relate to traditional Icelandic or Hungarian textiles?  Help an artist find out and then share it with you!

 

Perks!  

Most of the gifts are rare hand-embroidered textiles that I designed with Hungarian women in Transylvania, Romania.  Written embroidery is becoming harder and harder to find outside of museums when traveling, especially this particular style from the Kalotaszeg region.  You are receiving a special piece of embroidery that combines the contemporary and traditional, created with quality materials and fair wages paid to the artisans.

Other gifts include embroidery how-to kits, private lessons, and a special lunch and workshop in the San Francisco Bay Area.

ThreadWritten Project Bag:

Organic cotton bag with red silkscreened design from a Hungarian written embroidery pattern from Transylvania, Romania. 11.5 x 10 inches.

Written Embroidery Kit:

Learn the written stitch at home and make a small drawstring bag.  Instructions and materials packed in the Project Bag.

Small Tulip Embroidery Hanging:

Embroidery measures 8 x 2.5 inches on a  12 x 9 piece of linen/cotton blend fabric made in Romania.  Red on Natural.   *This embroidery is also available 'as is' for your own creative projects.

3 Tulip Embroidery (as is):

Embroidery measures 9 x 7 inches on a 17 x 16 inch piece of linen.

3 of each color available as is. Colorways: B-G = Black thread on Grey linen, R-N = Red on Natural, C-N = Cream thread on Natural linen, B-N = Black on Natural linen, C-N = Cream on Grey Linen.

3 Tulip Embroidery Framed:

Embroidery framed without glass, finished size 12 x 12 inches, 2 inch depth.  

Choose from any of the colors shown above!

Lg. Tulip Embroid. (as is):

Embroidery measures 13 x 8 inches on a 24 x 18 inch piece of linen.

Colorways indicated individually at right.  R-N = Red on Natural, B-G = Black thread on Grey linen, C-N = Cream thread on Natural linen, C-N = Cream on Natural Linen, B-N = Black on Natural linen.

ThreadWritten Pillow:

Linen/cotton blend pillow with cotton embroidery made by women in Transylvania, Romania. Over 12 hours of hand-embroidery. Pillow measures 10 x 14 inches.  Only 5 left!!!

Images from Transylvania. Artisans who embroidered and women who supported the project:

Teaching a written embroidery workshop, 2017:

Student work (and what you'll make with the kit):

 

Recent Press

http://handeyemagazine.com/content/written-threads

http://www.feelingstitchy.com/2017/04/threadwri...

story:
My name is Jessica Gokey. I live on the Lac Courte Oreilles Reservation in Hayward Wisconsin. I have been beading for over ten years and have currents works of beadwork art in local art galleries and have been commissioned to make pieces of beadwork for people. I work on my beadwork fulltime to keep the tradition alive and help sustain my family. My plan is to bring community members together to teach the importance of Native Traditions and to keep the art of traditional beadwork alive. I have experience with teaching tribal traditions and treaty rights to youth and community members though my past job and Conservation Warden. But with changes in my life and my choice to be a stay at home mother, I have worked on my beadwork fulltime now to be at home to raise my son. But the love of beadwork, traditions, and teaching is part of my life that I want to continue to share with my community members.

Keeping tradition alive is something important in my life as an Ojibwe Native American. One tradition that has become a huge part of my life is beadwork. I have been beading for over ten years. I learned how to bead while watching my aunt bead just like her elder before her taught her. Through my beadwork I keep our traditions alive using traditional Ojibwe patterns and learning history and importance of beadwork to our people.

What’s the plan? Well my plan is to bring together our youth or inexperienced people in the community with more experienced beaders such as myself. I will teach the inexperienced people how to bead, why it’s so important to keep this tradition alive, and how to make traditional patterns of our Ojibwe people.

Am I just going to teach how to bead? Yes and No. I will be teaching students how to bead but also how to make item to bead on such as: moccasins, pipe bags, tobacco pouches, belts, medallions, and other items students show interest on how to make and apply beadwork to.

Although it would be nice to get up right now to do this now, the lack of supplies holds me back. My plan is to raise $5,000 for supplies to teach my students, handouts and teaching materials, and compensation to fellow teachers for their time.

With the start-up of this collective beading program curriculum, I am hoping with the successful funds raised and student turn-out the long term goal is to be able to sustain this program with community involvement and tribal school/college/enterprises support.

The challenge this project may face is lack of support for future long-term sustainment. But how can I overcome this? With the self determination to get support from the tribal school/college/enterprises support, my plan is to have a solid program already established and a curriculum made to show tribal school/college/enterprises that this project is a great investment to support and for to help keep our native traditions alive for our future generations to come.

With generous donations, donors will recieve hand made native american items made by myself, Jessica Gokey to show appreciation to help preserve native traditions. All items are made by hand and are one of a kind, no item is duplicated with same designs or beadwork. You can own a piece of native american tradition with your generous donation.

I will teach the inexperienced people how to bead, why it’s so important to keep this tradition alive, and how to make traditional patterns of our Ojibwe people.
Am I just going to teach how to bead? Yes and No. I will be teaching students how to bead but also how to make item to bead on such as: moccasins, pipe bags, tobacco pouches, belts, medallions, and other items students show interest on how to make and apply beadwork to.
Although it would be nice to get up right now to do this now, the lack of supplies holds me back. My plan is to raise $5,000 for supplies to teach my students, handouts and teaching materials, and compensation to fellow teachers for their time.
With the start-up of this collective beading program curriculum, I am hoping with the successful funds raised and student turn-out the long term goal is to be able to sustain this program with community involvement and tribal school/college/enterprises support.
The challenge this project may face is lack of support for future long-term sustainment. But how can I overcome this? With the self determination to get support from the tribal school/college/enterprises support, my plan is to have a solid program already established and a curriculum made to show tribal school/college/enterprises that this project is a great investment to support and for to help keep our native traditions alive for our future generations to come.
With generous donations, donors will recieve hand made native american items made by myself, Jessica Gokey to show appreciation to help preserve native traditions. All items are made by hand and are one of a kind, no item is duplicated with same designs or beadwork. You can own a piece of native american tradition with your generous donation.

story:
We used a blooper video because the girls were just SO CUTE!!, My apologies for my mess up at the end.

**This is our last week, and a grand opening is no longer possible.  We had to repair more then we expected**

We own Skin Alternative, an upscale tattoo studio.  Troy is the artist/owner with over 14 years experience. Kate is the accountant/shop manager/marketing designer, etc. We also have an employee, Joseph Bawden who has 3 years experience and is growing both professionally and talent wise every day.  We are family oriented and based on creating personal connections and a professional experience.  We have been in business for 4 years. We had our studio in Hillside, NJ and due to a dispute with our landlord it was in our family's best interest to close down and vacate the property.

We are now setting up our studio in the town of Scotch Plains,NJ. Getting our shop set up in Scotch Plains is going to be the turning point for our business, and our family.  Where we were fighting a deteriorating building and area, we will now be in a legitimate location with higher traffic and more customers. 

We are the first, and only allowed tattoo studio in Scotch Plains and we believe we are a great studio for the town. We are above the bar with talent and individual attention. We treat our customers like family. Since we are the first and only, we had to go before a zoning board to get special approval.  We faced the following costs.

$2,000 Lawyer, $3,000 Planner, $1,800 Zoning fees

We had some money saved up from when our business was open, but it was not nearly enough to cover these costs and pay the bills at our house and cover construction to open the new studio.

This is where we need your help.  Construction is costing us $5,000-$6,000 and we do not have the money available to cover that AND setup and have a grand opening.  A grand opening is important to us to let the town know what we are all about and to provide our own merchandise to give out.  We want to reassure them that they made a good decision allowing us to be in their town. We are not your typical "tattoo shop" and we want to world to know it.

We are offering perk packages ranging from $2 which gets you a high quality vinyl weather-resistant sticker and a personally hand-written thank you note from Kate and the girls, to $400 for a gift card valued at $500 plus the sticker and thank you. Packages include body jewelry, clothing, and various merchandise.

If we do not reach our goal, we are still going to open the Scotch Plains Studio, but funding would be very tight for ourselves and our home.

We truly feel that setting up our studio in Scotch Plains would give the residents of the town a chance to get their tattoos local and invest their money back into their community.  We always have donated to the local police, fire and school fundraisers.  We are looking into setting up space for local artists to show off some of their artwork through a "local artist of the month" program.  And we will also be showcasing some additional artwork from artists we know.

If we are blessed enough to raise more then we are asking, then any additional money will go towards giving back whether it be through sponsorships or local events.

 

If you can't donate, please spread the word. Every little bit helps.

story:
THE WAY OF THE WHITE SAND

Hello Friends 

My name is Louis Schwadron and after a decade of writing, recording and touring internationally with bands, artists and musicians of all walks, I now front a 5-piece dreamrock band called SKY WHITE TIGER here in New York City.

We are raising money for a once-in-a-lifetime concert experience and live audio/video recording in a Brooklyn Cathedral this October called THE WAY OF THE WHITE SAND. Audiences are invited to lie on a sea of white fur and experience the expanded live "surround sound" of 5-piece band, choir, strings, gamelan ensemble performing a seamless concept album from various areas of the cathedral -surrounding the audience. This will be the very first of a series of these live concert experiences we will develop with visual artists and projectionisits in large scale spaces all over the world with this material.

THE WAY OF THE WHITE SAND doubles as the name of the upcoming live album and an original fantasy story I've written to accompany the album. Benton C Bainbridge (Beastie Boys, TV on the Radio, Whitney, MOMA, EMPAC) will shoot and edit original content then work with members of Light Harvest Studio to interpret the story in original light art and video projections on various moons and surfaces around the cathedral. 

We have been invited by the Bobby Redd Project space to put on this show Oct 6th. In order to do this we need to think like theater producers rather than  performers of this music.  While the space is bold and beautiful - it is up to us to bring in everything but the cathedral itself.

Your contributions make it possible to pay all of the performers, live audio engineers, lighting designer, video projectionists, content development with Benton Bainbridge for the projections, light and projector rentals, audio rental gear for live sound and multitracked recording, white (faux) fur carpeting, large scale spherical screens + riggers, live camera crew , video editors, liquor, bartenders, programs, pretty much everything you will experience OCT 6th and the costs to capture, edit and repackage the experience in audio and video formats once its through - as a thank you to all of you!

We've been curating these multi-media dreamrock concert experiences for a several years now but never on this scale.

Come with us to make something amazing happen.

We need your help to launch LUCY into the SKY with TIGERS!

Thank you for your time and support and we look forward to sharing this experience with you very soon!
 
LOVE
LOUIS

 

if you'd like to enjoy any of the music of SKY WHITE TIGER feel free ot visit www.skywhitetiger.com

or at our vimeo page-  https://vimeo.com/user3275061

a link to Benton c Bainbridge's work - https://vimeo.com/bentonc

story:
LBRC Needs You!

Our Mission: LondonBRC’s (LBRC) goal is to bring some of the iconic structures of London (House of Commons/Houses of Parliament, Tower Bridge and Tower of London) to the Playa of Black Rock City as a fully functioning interactive art installation for Burning Man 2013.  With the hope of incorporating the integral elements of these landmarks into the landscape of community, culture and core principles that is The Burning Man Project. 

The entire project, detailed below, is slated to be planned in tiers, based on resources and funding, with each structure built as a phase designed to carry itself individually and work together as a whole.

Current Project: Tier 1. Phases 1 – 1B. One of the most exciting aspects of these structures and our first full phase of the project will be a fully functioning, free standing House of Commons, to be used for both planned and open discussions & forums by all, to discuss any relevant topics, ranging from world matters to topics within Burning Man itself. The walls of the House of Commons will be lined with interactive artwork from our volunteers and artists around the world with the exterior of the structure used as a projection canvas at night (Sample pic here!). Tier 1B incorporates our vision of Elizabeth Tower attached to the House of Commons, a vision where the tower's clock faces will also interact with other projects on the Playa.

Future Possible Tiers:
Tier 2. Houses of Parliament. Designed as a 4-story structure, incorporating the remaining elements of our Houses of Parliament, with Ye Olde Ale House , a working indoor Theatre/Cinema, art rooms and corridors lined with portraits of famous Royals & characters from British history, all donated by artists from around the world.

Tier 3. Tower Bridge will connect both The Houses of Parliament and Tower of London on the 1st floor. The bridge itself will also showcase performance art incorporating a number of different artists and groups on the Playa.

Tier 4. Tower of London will be home to a dungeon, theatrical style brothel, a history room telling tales of the Tower of London and other historical facts and photos. The Tower will also be designed with a flat roof to be used a large viewing platform.

MORE VIDEOS & IMAGES for the whole project at: www.londonbrc.com

And YES we are burning it!

OK...Now that you read ALL about the project, time to ask what do WE need and why should YOU donate?!

Your donations help us on so many levels! From raw materials: every piece of timber, every screw and every nail, to the tools and paint to put our vision together, to transporting LondonBRC to the playa...and So Much More! Every dollar (or pound) you graciously give us is actively spent as efficiently as possible to make LBRC happen for us all! And we need all of you to make this possible for our team, crew and tireless volunteers...So now that you know what we need...check out OUR AWESOMES perks (and yes, we will have MORE!) to see what you get!

We heart volunteers too...Of course we need money! But we also know that time and resources are priceless, so if you just can't spare a dollar or a pound, please visit our volunteer resources on line and join us: LBRC FB Volunteer Group

THANK YOU AND DON'T FORGET...EVERY DOLLAR (OR POUND) HELPS!

SEE YOU ON THE PLAYA!

THE EN!GMA CREW
