story:
Summary

THE ORANGE MARTINI PROJECT-Modernism Today 

A one-of-a-kind art exhibit featuring lenticular prints that "move" when viewed from different angles, and showcases fun, Palm Springs lifestyle scenes, photographed by Lani Garfield. The series of 9 prints will be unveiled at the Palm Springs Hilton lobby as part of Modernism Week on February 13, 2013, and also along Palm Canyon in participating uptown district stores.  Proceeds from these two shows will go to The Palm Springs High School Arts Institute.

 

 The Orange Martini Project is a series of unconventionally displayed photographs featuring Palm Springs and it's amazing community. With participation from various local friends, artists, businesses, and even the mayor- Lani has been able to capture the essence of the Modern lifestyle here in PS. The lenticular prints will show a scene in "motion" when viewed from one side or another. The allure of this fair city, which is dedicated to the appreciation and preservation of modernist architecture, design, and living, has served in the past and present as a playground to the stars and it's residents.  The interactive display showcases the hip, locally found clothes and iconic mid-century modern architecture in a way that blurs the line between today and the days when The Rat Pack stayed and played in the desert.

 "It's not just about looking backwards with nostalgia", Garfield explains. "It's about looking forward. It's how we live today in a place with a colorful, fun, architecturally significant history." 

 The series of nine 24x36" limited edition, signed and numbered, lenticular prints will be displayed at the Palm Springs Hilton, as well as 9 retailers and restaurants throughout the Uptown Design District of Palm Springs. Visitors are encouraged to enjoy a "Passport to Palm Springs" adventure and visit all 9 businesses on a "hunt" for all 9 prints. A passport can be picked up at any of the locations to start with, and at each stop a "passport stamp" will be given. Full passports can be redeemed for a complimentary Orange Martini from participating restaurants included in the hunt! Smaller 5x7 cards of the series will be available in a limited run. Print proceeds go to The Arts Institute at PSHS. 

 The Arts Institute at Palm Springs High School is a model arts education program offering interested high school students enhanced learning experiences for artistic growth, preparing them for educational and job opportunities in the arts beyond high school. One of the key programs provided is the "Mentoring Program". Students receive real-life experience with an established artist in their art trade and learn how they can turn their passion for art into a career. For the past 5 years Lani has mentored 2 students a year and taught them the practical working  knowledge of photography as they enter her world of photographing "the jet set" here in Palm Springs. 

 

Our contributors thus far include: 

LOCATIONS provided by:

Doug Kinzley, Rod & Cindra Stolk, Dorothy & Harold Meyerman, Wil Stiles & Molly Bondhus, Julie Rodgers & Mitch Cowley, Gary & Joan Gand, James Hume, Odessa Christiana, and Chris Menrad

MODELS: 

Alane Morales, Charles Montgomery, Donna Sturgeon, Doug Kinzley, Gabreilla Romo, Jessey Gilbertson, Leisa Austin, Nicholas Ellis, Tristan Milanovich, Ashley Chernesky, Dan Ball, Jaci Fitzsimons, Jonas Adceff, Roberto Madero, Terra Perezchica, Aimee Sorby, Daizy Maldonado, Jessica Jackson, Joseph Halm, Tiffani Labue, Amy Blasdel, Arlene Amick, Beth Moon, Dorothy Meyerman, Harold Meyerman, Howard Moffett, Kelly McLean, Paul Lewin, Stephen Pougnet, William Kopelk, Andrew Dean Hunt, Ashley Rosenow, Erik Rosenow, Athena Crabtree, Brooke Whitney, Erin Caroll, Jade T. Nelson, Jennifer Roose, Jeremy Johnson, Jerry Ayala, Jonny Westom, Julie Westom, Luis Alberto, Martin Lowery, Rich Young, Sasha Young, Shaelee Espinosa, Steve Henke, Will Sturgeon, Cindra Stolk, Rod Stolk, Kate Swarner, Ron Swarner, Troy Bankord, Amanda Cherrey, Brent Middleton, Craig Fury, Greg Middleton, Greg Wolfson, Jennifer Isherwood, Jesse Isherwood, Marc Samson, Nicole Middleton, Jamie Owa, Ashley Pintor, Colin Pintor, Larry Weitz, Laura Weitz, Leo Rodriquez, Odessa Christiana, Ryan Berit and Taylor Ann Trad. 

CLOTHES provided by:

Wil Stiles, William Miller, Trina Turk, Cindra Stolk, Carol Dean and Odessa Christiana 

HAIR & MAKEUP provided by:

Stacy Hall, Jerry Ayala, Roberto Madera, Terra Perezchica, Giancarlo Tenebruso, Chip Tuvman, Vea Serna, Odessa Christiana and Joy Fields

STYLING provided by:

Odessa Christiana

SET CREWS:

James Hume, Dre Naylor, Shaelee Espinosa, Brooke Whitney, John Warden, Adam Hyatt, Jack Garfield and Jim Gazan

VIDEOGRAPHER:

Cindy Bookout

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our community has generously contributed in various way to help us offset our original costs and realize this goal, but we still need your help! Some of the things we still need help with are:

Printing costs

Printing of the large lenticular photos and display costs- easles, mounting, ect. 

Printing of the 12x12" and 5x7" prints and packaging

Printing costs for the Passport to Palm Springs Adventure and stamps.

Here is a link to a video that explains the printing process indepth: 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VRNpFp2L8UY

Crew costs

Costuming 

Location Fees

Transportation fees for models and crew

Equipment rental

Craft services for 9 shoots

Permit costs/application fees for city permits to sell images 

Office supplies

 

Rewards- Packages

We have put together, again with the generosity of our community, some fantastic reward packages! We have packages for locals and out of town guests, limited edition signed and numbered, lenticular prints from the series, behind the scenes video from the shoots, and tickets to be the first to see the series in print at our fabulous opening night gala where the Orange Martinis will be flowing and you can mix and mingle with some of the hippest people in town- the models and crew from all 9 OMP shoots and the project's valued supporters!

If these packages sound as tempting to you as they do to us and we end up OVER funded, the money will go towards the next year's project, "Palm Springs In Action" and, of course, the PSHS Arts Institute. 

 

The Impact

The Arts Institute at Palm Springs High School is a very important organization to me. Our creative programs like art, photography, film and fashion are drastically underfunded. The Atrs Institute makes funds for field trips and supplies available that the teachers would otherwise have to pay for out of their own pockets. Creativite problem solving is a valuable resource in our world, the young minds of today deserve better oppertunities for becoming the creative leaders and innovators of tomorrow. I have personally worked with several students over the years as part of the mentoring program, and seeing these amazing young people with infinite potential and limited recources is saddening. Your contribution to this campaign is really a contribution to them. The Arts Institute awards scholarships for local college students as well, providing the financial assistance an otherwise unattainable valued education. An education that will assure them a stronger foothold in the professional world to today. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Spread the word about our campaign, let other people know about us!!

Share us on your social networking sites or email our campaign link!!

Equipment rental
Craft services for 9 shoots
Permit costs/application fees for city permits to sell images 
Office supplies
 
Rewards- Packages
We have put together, again with the generosity of our community, some fantastic reward packages! We have packages for locals and out of town guests, limited edition signed and numbered, lenticular prints from the series, behind the scenes video from the shoots, and tickets to be the first to see the series in print at our fabulous opening night gala where the Orange Martinis will be flowing and you can mix and mingle with some of the hippest people in town- the models and crew from all 9 OMP shoots and the project's valued supporters!
If these packages sound as tempting to you as they do to us and we end up OVER funded, the money will go towards the next year's project, "Palm Springs In Action" and, of course, the PSHS Arts Institute. 
 
The Impact
The Arts Institute at Palm Springs High School is a very important organization to me. Our creative programs like art, photography, film and fashion are drastically underfunded. The Atrs Institute makes funds for field trips and supplies available that the teachers would otherwise have to pay for out of their own pockets. Creativite problem solving is a valuable resource in our world, the young minds of today deserve better oppertunities for becoming the creative leaders and innovators of tomorrow. I have personally worked with several students over the years as part of the mentoring program, and seeing these amazing young people with infinite potential and limited recources is saddening. Your contribution to this campaign is really a contribution to them. The Arts Institute awards scholarships for local college students as well, providing the financial assistance an otherwise unattainable valued education. An education that will assure them a stronger foothold in the professional world to today. 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:
Spread the word about our campaign, let other people know about us!!
Share us on your social networking sites or email our campaign link!!

story:
Photo Art 2016 need your help...

We are an ambitious group of BA (Hons) Photographic Art students, currently organising and raising money for our graduate show and publication, launching June 2016! 

Taking place in Wales’ capital, Cardiff, the exhibition will showcase work from 14 diverse artists, coupled with a unique and exciting publication, designed and finished as a collective. 

We have grand plans for our publication: it's being designed by our own Emma Daly, and its ambitious format means it's going to be printed in sections, then assembled and finished by hand by us - this is where most of this money is going to go.

We appreciate all your contributions, but don't just need your money - help us by sharing this page, as well as our Facebook page!  There, you'll find our recent updates, previews, and information.

We’re capable of creating something really exciting, but we need your help - the more you're able to give us, the better our show and publication will be.

Thank you, and see you soon,

Photo Art 2016

Our Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/USWPhotographicArtGrad...

story:
Summary: An Art Book/Encyclopedia Of An Innovative Universe

Mystic Earth: The Infinite Fantasy will be a story that crosses the barriers of science fiction and fantasy, merging the two into a science fantasy drama.

An enormous planet nearly 10 times the size of our Earth comes under siege and
occupation by seemingly endless waves of science-fiction based settlers whose technology rivals that of Star Trek, Star Wars, Halo, Mass Effect, and Titan Fall. And to initiate more of the “wow-factor,” they also pilot giant robotic machines reminiscent of Gundam and Armored Core. These science fiction characters consist of both humans and aliens that used to be at war with each other but have long since formed an alliance in the wake of a catastrophe that threatened the existence of every being in the universe. There are Halo-like “super soldiers,” as well as warrior alien races, and those that rely purely on telepathic means of combat.

But even in the face of such overwhelming numbers and sophisticated technology the
Inhabitants of the planet of Mystic Earth are not without defense. They wield magic and have built their civilizations around its practice. Think of it as World of Warcraft, meets Skyrim, Jade Empire, The Lord of the Rings, Lineage, Dark Souls, Guild Wars, and Monster Hunter. This world is filled with castles, dungeons, floating cities, monasteries, and sacred temples, and is populated by elves, orcs, enormous dragon-like beasts, fairies, werewolves, vampires, undead, ghosts, giant golems, gods, mythic beings, humans of international descent(the world has medieval knights, Vikings, and samurais) as well as a plethora of other fantasy-based character types.

The main plot of this story revolves around the magic that resides within everything that lives on the planet. The sci-fi based settlers refer to it as “Mystic Particle” energy, while the native peoples call it “magic,” plain and simple. Mystic Energy though is in and of itself a technology that requires extensive study and practice in order to manipulate it to achieve a desired effect; as is often taught by mage guilds and wizardry halls. But what makes this energy so unique is that it can only be wielded by those born on the planet, and those that have an ancestry dating back to its birth, meaning that the settlers and even their future children don’t have the possibility of being able to produce and retain Mystic Particles.

This is the crux of the division. Those born within the depths of space have an ancestry that have experienced millenniums of countless extraordinary technological advancements, and as a result, have technology integrated into their very being. Whether it’s as subtle as cellular nano machines, or as visually apparent as a cybernetic body enhancement, technology is a part of their very existence, just as magic is a part of the Mystics themselves.

In this world, magic and technology are two very different things, and both refuse to function when wielded by an operator of the opposite side. For example, a Mystic-born can’t pilot a machine, or use a radiofrequency communication device; the Mystic Particles will short-circuit the devices, rendering them inoperable. And non-mystic, technology based individuals (often referred to as “Techs” for short) can’t bend the elements to their will, or use a rune stone to magically transport themselves from one place to another; nothing will happen because Mystic Particles are required.

Centuries of war have plagued the relationship and continue to stifle any chances of an overture for peace. Both sides see the other as the cause of the problem. Mystics view those coming from outer space as invaders, while the non-Mystic, technology based, Techs view their relocation to the planet as their only available option for survival, and think that the planet has more than enough room for more inhabitants. And on top of all that, the lands of Mystic Earth are divided into varying races and societies that often don’t take too kindly to Mystics of a different race and culture. So, as you can see, the politics of Mystic Earth can get pretty complicated.

Unless an uncommon union between a Mystic and a Tech births a “synchronized” child, there will be no hope for the two worlds of science and magic to come to understand each other. A Synced, half-breed child could be able to walk among both worlds and understand the secrets of each.

And of course, what sci-fi story would be complete without something reminiscent of
the aliens from aliens, the flood, the reapers, and the necromorphs from Dead Space. After all, why is it that the inhabitants of a vast and expansive universe are all running to the refuge of a single planet? Think about it. This story has bone-chilling horrors of its own.

 

An Unconventional Project:

What makes this project different than your standard story project is that I want to
make it a point that we don’t set any main characters, but instead focus on the setting of the stage, communicating the vision of the world in terms of environments and character types. Think of this project more as an encyclopedia and not a novel (although excerpts in a novel-like format may also be presented). In my opinion, this offers more room for expansion in case other writers get involved in the future, and offers the possibility of unrelated storylines and the birth of a truly infinite Intellectual Property.

What we are going to do if this project is successful is that we are going to send the
artists involved a more detailed brief of the world, and they’ll decide what it is that they’ll want to paint. Overall, they are going to have pretty much free-reign on the design concepts, because I believe that the sheer amount of diversity within this world demands it.

References for this universe, so that you can get an idea of the sci-fi and fantasy
aspects of it, include but are not limited to:

For Sci-Fi

Star Wars, Star Trek, Halo, Mass Effect, Aliens, Dead Space, Gears of War, Star
Craft, Zone of Enders, Gundam, Armored Core, and Appleseed.

And For Fantasy

World of WarCraft, The elder scrolls Skyrim, Jade Empire, The Lord of the rings,
Guild Wars, Lineage, Final Fantasy, Dark Souls, Escaflowne, and Monster Hunter.

On a more official note, this project is intended to be used to gain the attention
of the largest firms within the entertainment industry, so the submission of this concept alone will not be enough; it needs to be backed up by some of the most extraordinary art ever seen. That is why we need to put together this book.

I am going to be honest in that I believe that this Story has the potential to be the next huge multibillion dollar IP that spans across the media formats of Film, video games, toys, and novels. That is the intention of this endeavor; to gain the attention of major film companies like Disney, and AAA video game development studios. But that potential can only be reached with the help of sci-fi and fantasy enthusiasts like you. A person can have a good idea, but without the means to express that idea in terms of a visual medium, there is no way that a person will be able to gain the attention of potential investors, and the idea will never see the light of day.


 

The Impact

We are looking to initiate a project of incredible ambition. Think of it as a world comprised of various sci-fi and fantasy stories all wrapped up together into one gargantuan package with a coherent plot-line in terms of the setting of a universe with
infinite possibilities.

Political intrigue presented through a clash of civilizations within the realms of science fiction and fantasy has never been done like this before, and with such an enormous stable of designers and illustrators this concept can be brought to life with jaw-dropping flare and efficiency with the potential of sparking a dialog that had been previously abandoned within the field of entertainment for reasons rooted in marketability.

Mystic Earth though is different. It is not a mindless battle-fest of elves vs space marines, but is instead a story, a world that relates to the experiences of our own human history, and even though war and death is present throughout, conveys an underlying message of peace and friendship over hostilities, dialog over war, and that regardless of race, species, belief, technology, or place of birth, people can still learn
to understand each other even during the most lethal of times.

This art book/encyclopedia of Mystic Earth will be the start that gains the attention of the industry and will lead to this idea being expanded upon through books written by your favorite authors, movies played by your favorite actors, and video games made
by your favorite studios, as well as this concept being expanded upon through every other platform of entertainment. This idea will excite people’s imaginations so that they can see that all types of protagonists and unique stories can be made within a universe such as this. Seriously, this project will be a vessel that we can use to show the world that this concept of combining sci-fi and fantasy, two of the most financially successful genres in history, is something worth investing in.

The entire concept of this project runs on its potential. The question of what can we achieve with this is what drives this endeavor into Mystic Earth. If you are a fan of both science fiction and fantasy and want to see both presented in a way that has never been done before, and want to breathe life into a concept that has the potential to change the landscape of what the entertainment industry thinks can be done with
both genres, then you should support this project and step into a universe whose potential is that of incredible proportions.

So if you are interested in a unique project that crosses genres in a way that has not been explored all that much in the main-stream, but has the potential to become the next big thing, in movies (think The Lord of the Rings meets Star Wars), in games (think Mass Effect meets Skyrim), and in tv shows (think Game of Thrones meets Galactica), and if you want to see something like this happen, to see sci-fi vs fantasy as a valid cross-genre and presented through all forms of entertainment, then you should let the industry know that there is a demand for this, and join with us in making
this project a reality.

 

A universe such as this can only be made possible with your help!

Please spread the word about this project. Only when the entertainment industry sees that there is a demand for something like this will this concept of bringing sci-fi vs fantasy to the mainstream be given a chance.

By commissioning these artists to put together this book we'll be able to show the world the possibilities that a universe like this presents. But it is only with your help that we can spread the word to get enough people to join in on this.

What you will be getting if you support this project will not only be an incredible art book that shows and explains to you the wonders and conflicts of this universe, but you will also be paving the way for sci-fi vs fantasy to be brought to every other platform of entertainment simply because of the potential that an opportunity such as this presents.

So please, spread the word as much as you can, through facebook, twitter, and everywhere else! Because it is only with your help that we can succeed in changing the landscape of the industry, and bring life to that which we have always wanted to see in movies, and video games, and to read about in novels.

Every person that donates 30$ or more will have their name written in this book, and those that purchace a physical copy will be able to submit text next to their name inside the book that explains why they want to see sci-fi vs fantasy brought to the mainstream of entertainment and what they hope this book will achieve.

Let the world forever know that you had something to do with bringing this concept to a reality! And remember that the main goal of this campaign is to spark a science fiction vs fantasy revolution of ideas... Support us to become a part of it! :D

story:
A knight and his dragon

My name is Bryn Fraker. I am a senior animation student at the California College of the Arts. My short film, "Ignite," features stop motion animation. Everything you see on the screen was meticulously made by hand, the characters, the environment, the props. The illusion of movement is created by moving the puppet a tiny bit, take a picture, repeat. "Ignite" follows the antics that arise when a lowly knight tries to roast a hotdog with dragon fire. The dragon, of course has other ideas. 

My passion lies with stop motion animation and fabrication. I love taking drawings and turning them into something you can touch. I have been pulling out all the stops will making the world of "Ignite."

Peet is a playful, curious and mischievous dragon. He is a fully posable puppet. From the tip of his nose to his tiny dragon toes he was entirely crafted by hand. He can blink, yawn, run around, wag his tail, and flap his wings. 

Bill the Knight would best be described as a knight-in-dull-armour, although he made the dragon riding team, he is hapless and often left behind. He is also a fully posable puppet, with silicon hands, an embroidered tunic, and weathered, dinged-up helmet. 

   

It's time to bring them to life

I have been working on this film with a student budget, your support will help me cover the expenses of 

  • Materials to build the puppets and sets
  • Software to film and edit the stop motion project
  • Promotion at festivals and events

I have been working on this film for the past six months, trying to make it the best that it can be. Not only has this film already taught me so much about story, character, and sheer technical skill of fabricating, it will help me break into the competitive animation industry when I graduate this spring. I hope "Ignite" will promote interest in stop motion animation, an increasingly niche field. I also hope my film will inspire other young women to make their own opportunities in animation. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation, you can still support "Ignite" by sharing this campaign with your friends and family! 

Interested in how I made "Ignite"? Follow it's progress on 

 www.brynfraker.blogspot.com

Want to Connect?

Facebook

Twitter

LinkedIn 

Check out my website

www.brynfraker.com

Thank you so much for your time!

story:
9th festival of the non-aligned comics NOVO DOBA
STRONGER FIRE
10th - 14th of October, 2018

Novo Doba Festival Support Shop Experience: STRONGER FIRE!

Novo Doba – your festival next door, your struggling artist friend, your mind-bending curator of impossible combinations, your favorite play list and home decor dealer, your loyal non-aligned ally, your union-representative and high school sweetheart. We are here again to offer you a unique opportunity to support top-notch underground production. -->Send us money, get stuff in return!

Novo Doba is a festival of non-aligned comics happening in and around Zemun and Belgrade (Serbia) at this time of the year. This autumn we are preparing the ninth edition of love and madness for you with a selected program of eye-opening visuals and exquisite experimental music.  Nine years is a long time for an underground festival, we are entering middle age. Too old to be stopped, too experienced to be naive, too stubborn to slow down – we named the edition STRONGER FIRE. The festival vision is an intersection between visual arts, experimental music, small-press publishing, people, places and production. If you are in the neighborhood, come by and join the circus. If you can't come by, please consider getting some perks from this campaign. We can do so much with so little.

What do we need money for? This year we managed to get some funding for the visual program, but need to hustle for music. Stronger fire from the speakers with concerts by Trrmà (Italy), Mimi Kawouin (France), Bonne Humeur Provisoire (France), Feberdröm (Sweden), Mangulica FM (Serbia),  Lenhart Tapes (Serbia), Moussaka (Serbia)... Your cash will be spent on travel expenses, renting equipment and a sound technician. If there is anything left after that we will distribute it as well-deserved fees among the proletarians. 

Novo Doba is self-organized and financed by voluntary work, public funding and hustling paper. At the heart of the collective stands the graphic workshop The Matriarchy with an all-year-round production of posters, prints, books and graphics by some of the most interesting artists we know. To fill the hole in the festival budget we are preparing an exclusive series of 9 new silk screened posters by the admirable round-up of artists exhibiting their works on this year's festival: Anne Van der Linden (France), Abraham Diaz (Mexico), Yvan Alagbé (France), Simon Häussle (Austria), Veljko Onjin (Serbia), Art Brut Serbia (Serbia), Anna Ehrlemark (Sweden), Bitlsti (Serbia), Vojvoda Milica (Serbia) and Andrej Bunuševac (Serbia).

But that's not all. You can also get your hands on the ninth edition of the infamous festival catalogue, with scandalous texts, in-depth interviews, never-seen graphics, intimate confessions and cunning fiction. See the perks on the right for more desirable objects at bargain prices. 

The shop is open. 

Thank you so much. /Novo Doba crew

 

Thank you to Bruno, Anna, and Subsite for photos and video material from the 8th edition of the Novo doba festival!
story_txt:
9th festival of the non-aligned comics NOVO DOBASTRONGER FIRE10th - 14th of October, 2018
Novo Doba Festival Support Shop Experience: STRONGER FIRE!
Novo Doba – your festival next door, your struggling artist friend, your mind-bending curator of impossible combinations, your favorite play list and home decor dealer, your loyal non-aligned ally, your union-representative and high school sweetheart. We are here again to offer you a unique opportunity to support top-notch underground production. -->Send us money, get stuff in return!

Novo Doba is a festival of non-aligned comics happening in and around Zemun and Belgrade (Serbia) at this time of the year. This autumn we are preparing the ninth edition of love and madness for you with a selected program of eye-opening visuals and exquisite experimental music.  Nine years is a long time for an underground festival, we are entering middle age. Too old to be stopped, too experienced to be naive, too stubborn to slow down – we named the edition STRONGER FIRE. The festival vision is an intersection between visual arts, experimental music, small-press publishing, people, places and production. If you are in the neighborhood, come by and join the circus. If you can't come by, please consider getting some perks from this campaign. We can do so much with so little.


What do we need money for? This year we managed to get some funding for the visual program, but need to hustle for music. Stronger fire from the speakers with concerts by Trrmà (Italy), Mimi Kawouin (France), Bonne Humeur Provisoire (France), Feberdröm (Sweden), Mangulica FM (Serbia),  Lenhart Tapes (Serbia), Moussaka (Serbia)... Your cash will be spent on travel expenses, renting equipment and a sound technician. If there is anything left after that we will distribute it as well-deserved fees among the proletarians. 


Novo Doba is self-organized and financed by voluntary work, public funding and hustling paper. At the heart of the collective stands the graphic workshop The Matriarchy with an all-year-round production of posters, prints, books and graphics by some of the most interesting artists we know. To fill the hole in the festival budget we are preparing an exclusive series of 9 new silk screened posters by the admirable round-up of artists exhibiting their works on this year's festival: Anne Van der Linden (France), Abraham Diaz (Mexico), Yvan Alagbé (France), Simon Häussle (Austria), Veljko Onjin (Serbia), Art Brut Serbia (Serbia), Anna Ehrlemark (Sweden), Bitlsti (Serbia), Vojvoda Milica (Serbia) and Andrej Bunuševac (Serbia).

But that's not all. You can also get your hands on the ninth edition of the infamous festival catalogue, with scandalous texts, in-depth interviews, never-seen graphics, intimate confessions and cunning fiction. See the perks on the right for more desirable objects at bargain prices. 

The shop is open. 
Thank you so much. /Novo Doba crew

 
Thank you to Bruno, Anna, and Subsite for photos and video material from the 8th edition of the Novo doba festival!

story:
“There is no alternative.”

- Margaret Thatcher, 1978

 

Help us open a Museum of Neoliberalism in London

We are Darren Cullen and Gavin Grindon, and we've been curating and building a Museum of Neoliberalism which opened briefly at The World Transformed festival in Brighton. Now we want to bring it to London and open it, for free, to the public for six months or more, while planning a UK tour.

This project initially stemmed from an idea to build an anti-Thatcher Museum to rival the official and sycophantic "Margaret Thatcher Centre and Library", which was announced in 2015. As time wore on our project has become more focused on the ideology behind Thatcherism and what it has done to our communities, our jobs, our homes, and us as individuals.

The museum as it stands is still a small prototype of what both an expanded Museum of Neoliberalism and Thatcher Museum would look like, but we hope that by showcasing the sections we have made so far we can eventually raise the interest and funds needed to both add new displays and find it a permanent home.

Who We Are

Darren Cullen (aka Spelling Mistakes Cost Lives) is a satirical artist who's major projects include Pocket Money Loans, a payday loan shop for kids, which appeared in the street in London and Newcastle as well as at Dismaland, Glastonbury, and Roskilde festivals. He wrote a short film based on his Action Man: Battlefield Casualties toy sculptures, and has run and fulfilled two successful Kickstarter campaigns for a Mini Daily Mail, and an anti-army recruitment comic.

Gavin Grindon teaches curating and art history at the University of Essex. He co-curated Disobedient Objects at the V&A; parts of Banksy’s Dismaland and Walled Off Hotel; and was a member of Liberate Tate.

 


3D plan of the new museum layout

 

Where The Money Goes

The money we raise will be used to pay for building materials and running costs. While we will be re-using all the displays from the Brighton version, some of them need fixing and adding to, and some new displays are planned. The museum will need to be reconfigured for this new and smaller space, which will involve building stud-walls, and adding spot-lighting, sound and video.
 

If we don't reach our funding goal we will take what funds we do raise and use that to fund the initial launch and apply for other funding sources to keep the museum open as long as possible.

If we reach surpass our funding goal we will be able to start working on expanding the museum for a UK tour, as well as produce a museum catalogue (which will be available as a stretch reward) and put money into promotion.

The Impact

We want to get the museum open before the coming general election. We hope the museum could become an educational resource, provide inspiration for activists and an opportunity for the media to talk about an economic and social ideology that has remained invisible, even while the violence it has enacted in people's lives has not.

 

Risks & Challenges

Leegate Shopping Centre, where we're opening the museum, is planned to be demolished eventually by developers, but we very much doubt that will happen for at least another year.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't chip-in financially, there are other ways you can help. There are a few items we need for displays that would be gratefully received

  • iPhone 4 or Android phone (needs to be able to run VLC)
  • Plug extensions, 4-ways etc.
  • Computer monitor or flat screen TV
  • CCTV systems/individual cameras

In terms of helping with the build, we're looking for people who can

  • Do carpentry/joinery
  • Transport a perspex box from Leicester to London
  • Drop off leaflets at tourist spots/hotels etc

Thank you for reading this far, for your time and support.

www.museumofneoliberalism.com

story:
Watershed

Watershed is an opportunity to experience and explore an environmental portrait of one of the most prolific and undeniably political landscapes in the world – the Louisiana wetlands. Coupling video game technology with my own photographs of the swamp, I will create an interactive simulated world of coastal Louisiana. Watershed will exist in a space between reality and fantasy, a simulated world that uses social gaming methodologies to focus on the act of looking, mimicking the role policy makers have on political landscapes.

Growing up near Barataria Bay in New Orleans, the floating wilderness of the swamp was a vital part of my imagination. When I was invited to participate in USSSA and asked to choose a political theme, I instantly thought of home. Louisiana is losing it's protective border of marshes and barrier islands at the rate of roughly one acre every 33 minutes, a statistic desperately tied to our nation’s energy and food sources, as well the survival of the city of New Orleans against future storms. Watershed is an attempt to preserve, educate, and reimagine this landscape through photography.

Funds will be used directly for travel and expenses related to filming in Louisiana and post-production work back in NYC, as well as installation materials, printing, framing and shipping costs for the USSSA exhibition in Los Angeles in October.  The right side of this page details perks you will receive for your contribution, including new editions of prints and an exciting gift box. Donors at every level will be given the option to beta play-test the game during in early September, and all contributions over $25 will receive a final copy.  Follow on Tumblr and Pinterest to view work-in-progress and updates throughout the summer.

Visit the Art in Odd Places blog for an abridged interview about USSSA, Watershed, and more: http://www.artinoddplaces.org/blog/?p=1841

Thank you for your support! You can also help by sharing this video within your own social networks.

With gratitude,

Christy Speakman

USSSA

http://www.facebook.com/USSSartists

Thirteen contemporary artists will be forming “a more perfect union” in the month leading up to the Presidential Election, 2012. The project, “USSSA (united secret society of subversive artists),” will feature a highly diverse group of artists politically invested in the arts.  Through innovations to the curatorial model, this project becomes a venture where each artist presents a personally relevant perspective and engages the project as a space to work toward equal terms of support, respect and resolution. In bringing a collective voice to the issues that are most important to us, this group of artists will be calling attention to the dynamics of democratic process, documenting our innovative forms of collaboration, and bringing form to the patterns of real and actual change.

story:
• What: Mia Nelle Drøschler's public exhibition of artworks

  • When: Spring 2013

  • Where: Glasgow Botanic Gardens

  • Plus: Creative workshops for local children

 

'When I go into the glass houses and I see the strange plants of exotic lands, it seems to me that I enter into a dream.' 

Henri Rousseau

As an artist I am inspired by this quote by the French painter Henri Rousseau. It describes why he kept coming back to the Jardin des plantes, the botanical gardens in Paris, to find motifs and inspiration. In my paintings and photographic collages I create imagined landscapes including elements taken from reality. The results are dreamlike scenes with a reference to both surrealism and magical realism.

My imaginative landscape visions will be on display at Kibble Palace, the glass house in Glasgow Botanic Gardens, next spring, and it is my very first public exhibition.

I am also arranging three workshops for local children during the exhibition period, to support them in their creative process and help them use their imagination to create both paintings and collages. 

What We Need & What You Get

I need $4900 to cover all cost of material and studio rent. The material includes:

• Stretchers and canvas for eight paintings
• Acrylic and oil paint for eight paintings
• Brushes
• Fabric and wire for sculptures
• Materials for eight prints on aluminium
• Studio rent for three months

 

If I do not reach my target, the money raised will still go into my artistic practice, and in creating a new body of work, which is called 'Life Beneath The Surface'.  

You will be helping contribute to:


• Bringing art closer to where people live
• Supporting local children in their creative process
• Helping the artist cover her material costs

Please visit my website at www.mianelle.com  to read more about this project and to view other artworks of mine. 



Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute directly, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

Please spread the word about this campaign as your friends or family may have a penny to spare!
Thank you and I hope to see you at Kibble Palace in February!

Mia Nelle Droschler

 

Kibble Palace - Glasgow Botanic Garden

story:
A New Home For Ceramics

We started Saltstone Ceramics with the idea that an arts practice is an essential part of a well-balanced life. Since 2015 we've been teaching four students at a time how to get their hands dirty and bring art into their lives.

But we learned early on that, despite the huge demand for instruction, there was just no way for us to grow the classroom at our house. So for the past six months we've been scouring the city, looking for the perfect new home for our burgeoning community of artists and craftspeople.

And we found it! In the heart of Wallingford we discovered a beautiful, sunny space that is ready to be transformed into Seattle's newest arts center. We'll have room to triple the number of students and provide a home base for up to a dozen working artists. And we'll be able to provide a gallery to introduce Seattle to the best emerging and contemporary ceramicists from the Pacific Northwest and beyond.

What We Need & What You Get

The new space is basically just an empty box with old wires and pipes. We need to put in everything from a new floor to new sinks to new paint on the ceiling. We're buying new pottery wheels, a new kiln, and miles of storage racks. We need lightbulbs, mops, and all kinds of furniture to make the space useful.

We're committed to doing a ton of the work—we've already laid the new floor ourselves! But even so, getting this new studio ready is going to cost close to $50,000. Here's just a small part of our shopping list:

  • New waterproof moppable floor: $5,000
  • 8 new wheels with stools: $6,000
  • Kiln: $4,000
  • Four sinks, installed and plumbed: $5,000
  • Storefront sign: $2,500

We really believe in the value of this project, and we're investing $30,000 of our own savings (plus an entire summer of sweat equity) to bring the new shop to life. But we need you to help us bridge the funding gap. With your support we can hit the ground running and show Seattle just how essential art spaces are to the life of the city.

We've got fantastic perks to thank supporters. We're especially proud of our new community-centered logo. We've put it on the usual assortment of t-shirts and aprons and stickers, but the special-edition, once-in-a-lifetime backer's mugs are where it's really going to shine—literally! We're using real gold to transfer the logo onto the mugs (don't worry, it's not as complicated as it sounds).

Plus we're offering discounted gift certificates, a pottery party, and even a bit of woodworking for those of you who aren't into clay.

(Also note that images of perks are representative and might change.)

Risks & Challenges

This project is already moving forward, and we're looking forward to opening in September. But if we don't hit our goal for this fundraiser, we might have to open a little later, with fewer student spaces or a scaled-down gallery. Every contribution makes a difference when it comes to realizing our vision for the space. Thank you!

Renovations in a 75-year-old building are always an adventure. We've hired competent professionals to do the dirty work, but there's still a chance that we could uncover more than we bargained for. This might push back our opening date, but otherwise we're ready to do what it takes to get this important resource open to the public.

Other Ways You Can Help

We sincerely appreciate everyone's support, no matter how large or small. We really do! And even if you can't support us financially, there are many ways you can help us make this project a success:

  • Talk to your friends! Share the news about this campaign and our vision for connecting people through art experiences. 
  • Take a class with us! Registrations for classes in our shiny new space will open in August.
  • Sign up for the Saltstone Ceramics newsletter! You'll get updates on this project and learn when class registrations open up.
  • Come visit us when we open in September! We're on 45th in the heart of Wallingford. Talk to us about classes, meet the artists, and shop for beautiful functional ceramics.
  • Make art! This city needs more art!

The Impact

Seattle is changing at a breathtaking pace, and many folks feel like the essential art and culture of this town are being tossed aside. But these are the things that truly make a city livable, and we need to protect and invest in art spaces more than ever.

A studio like Saltstone Ceramics is an important part of engaging everyone in the world of art and craft. It connects people from all walks of life—fresh transplants and lifelong residents; tech nerds and line cooks and everyone in between. We're committed to making everyone feel welcome. We're committed to making a safe place for each person to explore their own creative practice.

If everything goes according to plan, we're going to open the doors of the new space to the public on September 1st, 2018. We hope to see you on opening day!

About The Team

Sarah Steininger Leroux (founder, teaching artist) started her ceramics career at the age of 16, mixing glazes in a professional studio. She has a BA in Ceramics (Goshen College) and an MFA in Arts Leadership (Seattle University). She founded Saltstone Ceramics in 2015 after a successful career in social work and non-profit management.

Phi Le (teaching artist) has been doing pottery professionally for 13 years, and has taught adults and kids at the Alki Beach Bathhouse and the Seward Park Clay Studio, as well as private lessons in his own studio. Phi studied ceramics at the University of Washington.

Jennifer Fujimoto (gallery curator) is a late-blooming multidisciplinary artist. After a successful graphic design career she discovered clay - a medium that allowed her to apply her design background and enthusiasm for Japanese folk art and textiles to tangible and useful, handmade products. Jennifer recently completed a work-study program at Pottery Northwest and was 2018 artist-in-residence at Saltstone Ceramics.

Coco Spadoni (teaching artist) has been part of Saltstone ceramics since Fall 2017. They have studied under a Canadian artist, Sandra Dolph and completed a work-study program at Pottery Northwest. With over five years of experience, they make both functional pottery and handbuilt sculpture.

Steve Leroux (handy person) is professional furniture maker, software engineer, and generally useful human. He has a BSc in Computer Science (UBC). Since 2012 he has been running Ruby Pear Woodworks, a fine furniture maker in Northwest Seattle.

Jennifer Fujimoto (gallery curator) is a late-blooming multidisciplinary artist. After a successful graphic design career she discovered clay - a medium that allowed her to apply her design background and enthusiasm for Japanese folk art and textiles to tangible and useful, handmade products. Jennifer recently completed a work-study program at Pottery Northwest and was 2018 artist-in-residence at Saltstone Ceramics.
Coco Spadoni (teaching artist) has been part of Saltstone ceramics since Fall 2017. They have studied under a Canadian artist, Sandra Dolph and completed a work-study program at Pottery Northwest. With over five years of experience, they make both functional pottery and handbuilt sculpture.
Steve Leroux (handy person) is professional furniture maker, software engineer, and generally useful human. He has a BSc in Computer Science (UBC). Since 2012 he has been running Ruby Pear Woodworks, a fine furniture maker in Northwest Seattle.

story:
The Jon Selikoff Collection houses a fantastic variety of antique wood type that has been printing posters, playbills, broadsides, and any other type of printed matter you can think of since the turn of the 19th century. I was given the opportunity to acquire Jon's collection and carry on his legacy after his passing last year. I want to share the collection with printers, designers, type enthusiasts, and any other kind of letter lover out there through a monthly poster subscription. Each month I will research one of the typefaces in the collection and create a new poster that draws from the history of type specimens and catalogs while adding to the current poster design revival. A one year subscription will come with 12 unique limited edition posters and it will do a world of good towards funding the necessary research and design time needed for a project like this. There is also 6 month subscription, as well as a single month option that allows you to choose which month you wish to receive a poster.  ​This project will continue Jon's mission by spreading love for wood type and letterpress. To honor his memory, 5% of all proceeds from this campaign will go to the ALSA Greater NY Chapter.

 

What am I doing here?

Hi there! My name is Ingrid Schindall and I am the owner of IS Projects, a public-access printmaking and book arts studio in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. I was recently given the opportunity to acquire the late Jon Selikoff’s letterpress collection formerly known as Vote For Letterpress. The collection contains an astounding and diverse array of antique wood type, lead type and two presses that will be an incredible resource for local and visiting artists. The collection is a huge investment that serendipitously provides me with the resources to start an undertaking that I’ve been dreaming of for years, a monthly type specimen subscription project. I need your help to get this project off the ground and make the Selikoff Collection a sustainable and cherished part of IS Projects that can be celebrated by type enthusiasts everywhere.

 

A brief history of the Selikoff Collection:

Vote For Letterpress was founded by Jon Selikoff in 2010 after he decided to take a leap and purchase an entire letterpress shop in Ithaca, New York, and move it to West Orange, New Jersey. Jon was running his own branding design company at the time and wanted a way to escape the digital world in his downtime and get his hands inky. Through the years of operation at Vote For Letterpress, Jon collaborated with several artists and designers to complete all different kinds of letterpress projects that pushed the medium forward and challenged the traditional notions of what letterpress can be. Sadly, Jon passed away in November last year, after a long, brave battle with ALS, leaving Vote For Letterpress without a proprietor. His family and friends wanted to be sure that his memory would be honored, and that his collection, which brought him so much joy, would remain intact. The collection will live on at IS Projects as the Jon Selikoff Collection, where it will continue to inspire contemporary printmakers to push the boundaries of letterpress and also honor and cherish the history of the craft. There's a bunch more info about Jon and the shop on the Vote For Letterpress website and you can check out articles written about his work here and here. 

Photo by: Cyndi Shattuck Photography

A little bit about IS Projects:

IS Projects is an independent public access printmaking studio in Fort Lauderdale, FL. It is the only studio of its kind in South Florida, providing training and access for local and visiting artists to printmaking and bookbinding equipment. It’s the only public access printmaking studio in South Florida and, as such, is vital resource to local and visiting artists who are interested in establishing their own printmaking practice. Based in the FATVillage Arts District, IS Projects enjoys hundreds of visitors each month during the FATVillage Artwalk as well as national and international visitors interested in all things art and printmaking. Since its opening in September 2014, I have, as the founder and director, worked tirelessly to cultivate a cohesive, supportive, and collaborative printmaking community in South Florida. My other main mission at the studio is to stimulate the evolution of printmaking and letterpress by encouraging contemporary artists to try the medium and push it to its limits. The Selikoff Collection is an incredible resource for the studio and all of the artists who work here. You can find out more about what IS Projects is all about and what we're up to on our website.

Photo by: Lara Rose Photography

Why does this matter?

This project is a celebration of the history of this collection as well as the history of the typefaces housed within it. Jon was an amazing man and top notch designer, he acquired most of his collection from a single printshop and now I am honoring the legacy of that shop and Jon’s shop by ensuring that this collection stays intact. I place a large value on the history of printing equipment and often ponder what a drawer of type or a press has printed before. All of my current presses are named after the printer that previously owned them as a way to preserve that piece of their history. This collection will be named the Jon Selikoff collection when it joins my studio as a way to celebrate Jon’s accomplishments and memory.

Letterpress lovers dream of having access to a collection as diverse and expansive as the Selikoff Collection and under the watchful eyes of IS Projects staff the collection will be able to be loved and preserved through use. IS Projects is a public access shop which means that we offer workshops, studio rental, tours, and demonstrations to anyone looking to get involved and get inky. We promote the continued evolution of letterpress printing through education and by encouraging contemporary artists and hobby printers to learn and practice.

 

Why do I need your help?

A project like this will require a considerable amount of time and energy each month out of my already intense business. Your funds will go toward making sure that I have the financial backing to step away from workshops and commissions for a bit each month and put in the hours of research, design, and printing that will be needed to make this project successful. As anyone who has tried their hand at letterpress printing knows, when time is money, you spend a lot more on design and set up than you ever could on materials.

Don't forget, 5% of all the proceeds from this project will be donated to the ALSA in Jon's Memory.

 

What will the posters look like?

In planning this project, I’ve developed an affinity for pangrams which are the perfect tool for showing off a complete typeface because they are sentences that include every letter of the alphabet. It was only after creating the first pangram for the project that I realized that JOn shared a similar interest in pangrams and, in fact, had a whole page dedicated to them on the Vote For Letterpress Website. In the first iteration of the poster project, I wrote a pangram inspired by the information that surfaced in my research on JB McCullagh. Each month I’ll write a new pangram that is somehow inspired by discoveries in the research, the aesthetics of the typeface itself, or the historical or contemporary uses for the typeface.

This is the first poster in the series with type from my personal collection. The color pallet is based on the portrait I found of JB McCullagh, the man the typeface was named after (pictured below.)

 

 

Here's a shot of the second poster in the series and the first to use type from the Selikoff Collection after its move to South Florida. Tuscan Extended is a wacky and polarizing typeface. What do you think of it?

Are there other ways to help?

If you’re not in a place to help out financially here are other ways to help support this project:

  • Share this project on social media: Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Pinterest and whatever other platforms you’re into. Seriously, anything helps!
  • Let your pals know about the project directly! “Hey have you heard of this new cool poster project on Indiegogo?” It's a great way to start a conversation.  Do you have some friends in Florida or who are planning to visit that would like to see the collection and posters in person? Send them our way!
  • Lastly, send us your stories! Are you an expert on a particular typeface? Do you have a funny story about a sign you saw with a specific typeface on it? Let us know and maybe it will influence one of the posters! Also feel free to send me your cool pangrams!

 

Serendipities 

Here are a few other conspicuous and endearing coincidences surrounding this acquisition that I thought you as a supporter might find interesting.

  • From Chris Fritton, the Itinerant Printer:  "I started The Itinerant Printer trip on January 26, 2015 at IS Projects in Ft. Lauderdale, FL, with Ingrid Schindall. I concluded the trip April 23, 2017, at Vote for Letterpress in Orange, NJ, with Jon Selikoff. If Ingrid were to purchase Jon’s legacy shop, the equipment from the very last shop I went to would be coming full-circle to the very first shop I visited on the journey. I don’t usually believe in fate, or kismet, or destiny, but were Ingrid to acquire this shop, it would bring things full circle in this small community of letterpress printers in a way that I never dreamed possible, and it would make for a beautiful, meaningful story about life, love, and what it means to be involved in a craft.”
  • In September 2015, Craig Ward and Linden Gledhill launched a Kickstarter campaign to letterpress print glyphs made from macro photographs of ferrofluid. My mom supported this campaign by ordering a print of the glyphs. The print was letterpress printed at Vote For Letterpress by Jon on his Vandercook SP20 that will be moving to Fort Lauderdale as a part of this collection. So there has been a print from Jon’s shop in my family’s home for a few years now acting as an ambassador to a shop that we never imagined we would get this involved with.
  • I learned about letterpress printing when I was at the Maryland Institute College of Art and the very first press I ever used was a Vandercook SP20. It was my favorite press throughout my time at MICA and I still think about it whenever I’m printing large format work on my SP15. I have been searching for an SP20 or SP25 for a years. When Chris sent me a draft of the text for his upcoming book, in my response I threw in the sentence “Also, if you hear of anyone selling an SP20 or SP25 PLEASE let me know.” at the end of the email without any real expectations. Chris responded a few minutes later with the information Jon’s shop including images from his visit to Vote For Letterpress. I never dreamed that I would get the opportunity to acquire a collection like this, lots of printer friends have told me that they got their collection through a once in a lifetime “unicorn” chance that came just at the right time for them and that’s what this shop is for me.  

 

All photos of Vote For Letterpress are courtesy of Cyndi Shattuck Photography

story:
Summary

Hello, my name is Chris McMullen and I am a Seattle artist who creates interactive, kinetic sculpture.

The GlobalArtAffairs Foundation has asked me to be part of “Time Space Existence,” the large art and architecture exhibition they organize bi-annually in the context of the Venice Architecture Biennale and I am thrilled to have received this distinctive invitation.

The exhibition is hosted and supported by the European Cultural Centre and will be presented in Palazzo Mora, Palazzo Bembo and Marinaressa Gardens in Venice Italy. The Venice Architectural Biennale addresses the academic side of architecture and provides an opportunity for architects and designers from around the world to showcase new projects.

Within “Time Space Existence,” there will be approximately 150 architects. I am one of only 30 sculptors who have been invited to participate this year which contributes to the extraordinary nature of this opportunity. The exhibition runs from May 26th through November 26th in 2018.

With more than 300,000 people expected to attend, exposure on this scale has the potential to provide me with further opportunity and support.

 

A little about my sculpture

This is Infrastructure, my most recent solo exhibition which ran Sept.-Oct. 2017 at Oxbow in Seattle, WA. This work represents the massive infrastructure that has been built and is required to move people and products back and forth, throughout the world, and works as a metaphor for the push-pull of interests constantly trying to get their way.

The installation consisted of two interactive, articulated cranes. Each crane invited up to three visitors to synchronize their interaction and communicate with one another in order to operate the crane and use it to stack blocks on to the scales next to them. When one scale out weighed the other, the trolley car mounted to the ceiling moved across the room.

I wanted to provide an opportunity for people to interact with the sculpture, and each other. It was very gratifying to see how they interacted with the work, how they perceived the challenge, and to witness the satisfaction and achievement they ultimately found as a result of their participation. This proved to be a remarkable experience. Groups of strangers encouraged each other and burst into applause and cheered when a block was hooked and successfully stacked on the scale.

 

The exhibition also included wall-mounted sculptures. Visitors were invited to turn a wheel which moved freight cars along the wall.  This is an experience where the turning of the wheel somehow takes you to a selfless place of wonder. The feedback in the wheel, coupled with the weighty sound of steel riding on steel creates a soothing and gratifying rhythm.

 

 

 

This show represents my current interests in art making where the sculpture is only complete when engaged by you.

The new sculpture I will create to take to Venice during the Architecture Biennale in 2018 is similar to these sculptures as it will be mounted to the wall, and have a hand-crank for visitors to turn and set the piece in motion. The visible movement and the sound it will create will be unique to its configuration.

If you'd like to see more of my work you can visit chrismcmullenproductions.com

 

Why I am asking for support

I have been working toward an opportunity to share my work internationally for many years and it has arrived. All the sculptures I have created in the last 18 years have been primarily self-funded but this opportunity comes with much greater expense than any of my previous endeavors. So I am reaching out to our local community and beyond. Any support you can provide would be genuinely appreciated.

All money donated will assist me in the creation and shipping of the sculpture as well as a little help with travel and lodging costs.

All funds raised will go directly to funding this endeavor.

Any contribution will be greatly appreciated. Please share this campaign far and wide.

Thank you for your support!

story:
Fotofringe 2014 is coming

My name is Jon Pountney, and I am a photographer living and working in Cardiff. For the last 4 years I have been working on a project called Cardiff before Cardiff http://cardiffbeforecardiff.tumblr.com/ which explores ideas of community, history, and memory through film documentary photography. Inspired by community involvement in the project and the experience of putting on a large 'CBC' exhibition, I have for the last few years been co-curating, with my friend Rebecca Wyn Kelly, a sequence of grassroots exhibitions called 'Art in the Warehouse', which provides a chance for emerging artists to show their work in an exciting and vibrant arena. Fotofringe 2013 was held as part of 'AITW' last May, in three different settings, giving over 20 photographers exposure in an unconventional and stimulating way. Rather than using established galleries, work was shown in a pub skittle alley, our warehouse, or postered directly onto city street walls. Interaction with the community was key, and many people who would not want to visit a gallery enjoyed seeing the work in this way. This year we want want to be bigger and better!
Funding 
Funding this year will allow us to achieve more- more artists, more work, better promotion. We are creating a responsive, intuitive festival, commissioning new work, and creating ways for the community to see the magic of true photography. This kind of festival is unique in Cardiff, and is not meant to be stuffy, formal, or academic. Have a look and see what we did last year- http://fotofringe.tumblr.com/
We already have eight great locations including CardiffMADE, Porters, and the Sherman Theatre.

story:
My name is Jill Connor and I began to develop Jill Connor Studio five years ago.  Over the past couple of years, I have focused the direction of my artwork towards product development and broadening my means of consumer outreach. As time advances, I continue to expand on my growing understanding of the consumer and where their interest lies in gifts for their friends, family and for themselves. Three constants that I continue to generate are: Color! Whimsy! Connection! The individual buyer is drawn to the carefree lifestyle that whimsical gifts can offer, and by using images that attract a broad audience, I create a special connection between each piece and its “person.” I have a background in retail development through working in my family’s retail design firm specializing in visual merchandising and have always taken into consideration the consumer and future product development when creating my art.

The intention of this campaign is to raise funds to exhibit during the Licensing Expo in Las Vegas on June 17, 18 and 19, 2014. This is “the world’s largest and most influential trade show dedicated to brand, character, entertainment and art licensing.” It would be an amazing opportunity to reach the next step in my licensing career to establish a capable and colorful brand which is recognized internationally.

           

My career highlights so far:

2009: Exhibited in my first arts festival in Oxford, Ohio

2010: Meeting the set designer for the American Pie sequel, American Reunion, during an arts festival in Cleveland, Ohio, where he bought several of my pieces for the set of the movie

2011: Exhibited during the National Stationery Show in New York City.

2011: Signed a contract with  PI Creative Art Poster Manufacturers for five of my Critter Collection designs

2011: Signed an on-going contract with Papyrus-Recycled Paper Greetings, where my greeting cards have been sold in both small shops as well as box stores such as Target and Meijer

2012: Signed a contract with Williams-Sonoma, Inc: Pottery Barn Kids, where I collaborated on 3 different projects, with 3 pieces ending up in stores nationwide

2013: Completed a major art project to set up the décor of a pediatrician’s office in Upper Arlington, Ohio, including exam rooms, hallways, and 5’ x 10’ stairwell piece.

What We Need

To fully attend the Licensing Expo would be closer to closer to $6,500, including exhibit space, travel and lodging. However every little bit helps! If my goal is not reached, then I still intend on attending the Licensing Expo as an attendee and making my contacts “grassroots-style”, and will take part in the workshops and lectures.

Why is Jill Connor Studio Different?

Jill Connor Studio offers an emotional connection to those that desire the vibrancy of color and conversation brought into their everyday life. We aim to be integrated into a variety of channels within the marketplace: greeting cards, fine art reproductions, fabric design, giftware, even animation! From children to young adults to grandparents, Jill Connor Studio has proven over the years to bridge a connection between the generations. By expanding Jill Connor Studio into the broader world of licensing, it offers the individual more options in which to share these connections with their family and friends.

·  An intense passion for color, connections and conversation.

·  An entrepreneurial spirit that constantly strives for product development and constant consumer outreach

·  A general appreciation for the “little things in life”

·  A personal connection to each creation

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone will be able to help with contributions; however you can still help by spreading the word! Please share my link with your friends and family, and maybe this can actually happen! 

Please see my website for more information: www.jillconnorstudio.com

Thank you!!

My
name is Jill Connor and I began to develop Jill Connor Studio five years
ago.  Over the past couple of years, I have focused the direction
of my artwork towards product development and broadening my means of consumer
outreach. As time advances, I continue to expand on my growing understanding of
the consumer and where their interest lies in gifts for their friends, family
and for themselves. Three constants that I continue to generate are: Color!
Whimsy! Connection! The individual buyer is drawn to the carefree lifestyle
that whimsical gifts can offer, and by using images that attract a broad
audience, I create a special connection between each piece and its “person.” I
have a background in retail development through working in my family’s retail
design firm specializing in visual merchandising and have always taken into
consideration the consumer and future product development when creating my art.

story:
Pour un Printemps - livre citoyen

L'aventure commence ! Artmour, issu du mouvement de société québécois ce printemps 2012, est un organisme à but non lucratif qui a pour mission d’organiser des coopérations artistiques ponctuelles, de façon indépendante ou en association avec d’autres OBNL qui partagent les valeurs d’Artmour : expression, participation, coopération et développement citoyens pour une société plus juste, plus égalitaire et plus démocratique. 

Le 14 avril 2012, Artmour lance son premier projet, imaginé et piloté par Jane D’eau, artiste montréalaise : l’écriture collective d’un livre citoyen Pour un Printemps.

Katia Lazdane, activiste, et Ani Shahbazian, écrivaine, co-fondatrices d’Artmour, prêtent leurs bras au projet. (Pour en savoir plus au sujet d'Artmour, visitez artmour.org)

Le livre : cette levée de fonds vise spécifiquement la production du livre imprimé Pour un Printemps et l'organisation de l'événement pour le lancement du livre. 

En effet, nous allons faire un premier tirage d'au moins 250 copies du livre : +/- 200 pages couleur, grand format (8.5" x 11" fermé - 11"x17" ouvert), couverture cartonnée et laminée pleine couleur, papier satiné de qualité, reliure allemande.

Le lancement aura lieu à Montréal, le 21 juin au Cabaret La Tulipe

Au programme pour la soirée du lancement : 

  • Projections géantes d'extraits du livre.
  • Rencontre avec les auteurs - ces nombreux professionnels, artistes, enfants, travailleurs, étudiants, parents, dont Jean Barbe, Normand Baillargeon, IVY, Hugo, Latulippe, Nicolas Lévesque, Catherine Lalonde, Queen KA, 22avril.org, Pink Bloc, le Regroupement des groupes écologistes du Québec, La Boîte Rouge, Fermaille, ArchiContre et tant d'autres qui nous excuserons de ne pas les citer ici - la liste complète des auteurs est régulièrement mise à jour ici. 
  • Lectures.
  • Tirages (affiches, copies du livre - première édition).
  • Table de présentation : visibilité pour les auteurs qui le désirent (artistes, collectifs, organismes etc.)
  • De nombreux musiciens invités et un SHOW POUR UN PRINTEMPS
  • Couverture médiatique gracieusement offerte par La Boîte Rouge. 

Au total, si nous comptons uniquement les frais d'impression pour le premier tirage du livre ainsi que les coûts pour l'organisation de la soirée du lancement (louer une salle + équipement et services), le montant s'élève déjà à 7,000 $. 

Ainsi, nous espérons atteindre ce montant grâce à cette campagne de financement sur Indiegogo - c'est le minimum qu'il nous faut pour garantir l'atteinte de nos objectifs. Si nous réussissons à dépasser cet objectif, ce sera encore mieux ! Selon les fonds amassés cela pourrait même nous permettre de faire un plus grand premier tirage... et/ou de tirer encore plus de copies gratuites du livre à la soirée du lancement (première édition).

Artmour est un organisme à but non lucratif enregistré et tous les dons Indiegogo iront vers le projet Pour un Printemps. Tous fonds excédentaires, qu'ils soient accumulés via cette levée de fond ou via la vente du livre,  s'il y en a, seront utilisés de la manière suivante : 

  • Rembourser les frais qui n'auront pas été couverts par cette levée de fond pour la première édition du livre et le lancement.
  • Un deuxième tirage du livre.
  • La production éventuelle de la version e-book (pour tablettes).
  • De futurs projets créatifs organisés par Artmour, toujours dans l'optique de permettre l'expression, la participation, la coopération et le développement citoyens pour une société plus juste, plus égalitaire et plus démocratique. 
  • Artmour s'engage à fournir sur le site web du projet après le lancement du livre (première semaine de juin) un état détaillé des fonds reçus et de leur utilisation pour les dépenses relatives au projet. Artmour est un organisme à but non lucratif enregistré et est légalement responsable du bon usage des fonds collectés. 

************************************************************************

Pour un Printemps - Citizen Book

The adventure begins! Artmour, risen from the Quebec social movement in the spring of 2012, is a not-for-profit organization whose mission is to organize punctual artistic cooperation projects, independently or in association with other not-for-profits that share Artmour's values : citizen expression, participation, cooperation and development for a more just, equal and democratic society.

On April 14th, 2012, Armour launches its first project, imagined and led by Montreal artist, Jane D'eau: a collective writing project by citizens, for citizens, Pour un Printemps.

Co-founders of Artmour, Katia Lazdane, activist, and Ani Shahbazian, writer, are on the project production team. (For more information on Artmour, visit artmour.org).

The book: this Indiegogo fundraiser specifically targets the production of the Pour un Printemps printed book and the organization of the book launch event.

Indeed, we will be printing a first edition of at least 250 copies of the book : +/- 200 colour pages, large format  (8.5" x 11" closed - 11"x17" open), soft full colour laminated cardboard cover, high quality satin paper,  perfect binding.

The book launch event will take place on June 21st at Cabaret La Tulipe.

The event program:

  • Wall projections of book excerpts.
  • Meet the authors – professionals, artists, children, workers, students, parents, including  Jean Barbe, Normand Baillargeon, IVY, Hugo, Latulippe, Nicolas Lévesque, Catherine Lalonde, Queen KA, 22avril.org, Pink Bloc, le Regroupement des groupes écologistes du Québec, La Boîte Rouge, Fermaille, ArchiContre, and so many others who will forgive us we hope for not citing them here – the complete author list is regularly updated here.
  • Readings.
  • Presentation table: author visibility for those who are interested (artists, collectives, organizations etc.)
  • Several guest musicians and a SHOW POUR UN PRINTEMPS
  • Full media coverage, courtesy of La Boîte Rouge.

Altogether, if we strictly count the printing cost for a first edition of the book along with the costs for the organization of the book launch event (renting a space + equipment and services), the bill is over 7,000 $.

Therefore, we hope to raise that amount thanks to this Indiegogo funding campaing – this is the least we can get away with if we want to guarantee reaching our goals for this project. If we exceed that amount, even better! Depending on the total funds we collect we might even be able to print a higher number of copies for the first edition… and/or give away even more free copies the night of the launch (first edition).

Artmour is a not-for-profit organization and all Indiegogo donations will go toward the Pour un Printemps project. Any funds left over, whether they are accumulated through this fundraiser or through book sales, will be used in the following manner:  

  • Reimbursing costs for printing the first edition of the book or for organizing the book launch which were not covered by this fundraiser.
  • Printing a second edition of the book.
  • Eventually producing an e-book version.
  • Funding future creative projects organized by Artmour, still within this goal of encouraging citizen expression, participation, cooperation and development for a more just, equal and democratic society.
  • Artmour will submit a full report on the project website detailing the funds collected as well as the actual project costs (after the launch, June 2012). Artmour is a registered organization and is legally accountable for its use of donated funds.
